Debiased Kernel Estimation of Spot Volatility in the Presence of Infinite Variation Jumps111All authors contributed equally to this work.

B. Cooper Boniece Department of Mathematics, Drexel University, PA 19104, USA (cooper.boniece@drexel.edu) Research supported in part by the NSF grant DMS-2413558.) José E. Figueroa-López Department of Statistics and Data Science, Washington University in St. Louis, St. Louis, MO 63130, USA (figueroa-lopez@wustl.edu). Research supported in part by the NSF grant: DMS-2413557. Tianwei Zhou Department of Statistics and Data Science, Washington University in St. Louis, St. Louis, MO 63130, USA (tianweizhou@wustl.edu).
(Oct., 2025)
Abstract

Volatility estimation is a central problem in financial econometrics, but becomes particularly challenging when jump activity is high, a phenomenon observed empirically in highly traded financial securities. In this paper, we revisit the problem of spot volatility estimation for an Itô semimartingale with jumps of unbounded variation. We construct truncated kernel-based estimators and debiased variants that extend the efficiency frontier for spot volatility estimation in terms of the jump activity index YY, raising the previous bound Y<4/3Y<4/3 to Y<20/11Y<20/11, thereby covering nearly the entire admissible range Y<2Y<2. Compared with earlier work, our approach attains smaller asymptotic variances through the use of unbounded kernels, is simpler to implement, and has broader applicability under more flexible model assumptions. A comprehensive simulation study confirms that our procedures substantially outperform competing methods in finite samples.

1 Introduction

Spot volatility estimation is a central problem in financial econometrics, underpinning numerous critical applications ranging from short-horizon risk management to derivatives pricing and hedging. Formally, the core task is to estimate the coefficient στ\sigma_{\tau} of the Brownian component of an Itô semimartingale XX at a fixed point of time τ\tau given high-frequency observations. For recent developments, we refer to [15, 7, 8, 19], as well as the monographs [10, 2] for in-depth treatments.

Widely observed empirically in high-frequency financial data, jumps are a salient feature of price dynamics, separate from fluctuations captured by diffusive movements in XX, and must be carefully accounted for when estimating volatility and related functionals of XX. When jump activity is high, however, standard estimation methods face inherent limitations, as estimation difficulty increases with the degree of jump activity of the underlying process. Three qualitatively distinct regimes can be distinguished: jumps of finite activity, infinite activity jumps of bounded variation, and infinite activity jumps of unbounded variation, the latter posing the greatest challenge, and the setting of the present work.

A fundamental approach to handling jumps is through truncation, introduced by [16]. Establishing jump-robustness for truncation-based methods classically amounts to two steps: suppose θ^n​(Δ1n​X,…,Δnn​X)\hat{\theta}_{n}(\Delta_{1}^{n}X,\dots,\Delta^{n}_{n}X) is an estimator of some functional θ\theta of the continuous component XcX^{c} of XX, where Δin​U:=Uti−Uti−1\Delta_{i}^{n}U:=U_{t_{i}}-U_{t_{i-1}} denotes the it​hi^{th} increment of a generic process UU sampled at times 0<t0<⋯<tn=T0<t_{0}<\dots<t_{n}=T during a finite time period [0,T][0,T]. In the first step, one shows that the (infeasible) estimator θ^nCont:=θ^n​(Δ1n​Xc,…,Δnn​Xc)\hat{\theta}^{\text{Cont}}_{n}:=\hat{\theta}_{n}(\Delta_{1}^{n}X^{c},\dots,\Delta_{n}^{n}X^{c}) is consistent and satisfies a central limit theorem (CLT) with, say, rate rnr_{n}:

1rn​(θ^n​(Δ1n​Xc,…,Δnn​Xc)−θ)⟶𝒟𝒩​(0,Vθ).\frac{1}{r_{n}}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n}(\Delta_{1}^{n}X^{c},\dots,\Delta_{n}^{n}X^{c})-\theta\right)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mathcal{D}}}{{\longrightarrow}}\mathcal{N}(0,V_{\theta}). (1)

Second, it is shown that, by choosing an appropriate threshold level vn↘0v_{n}\searrow{}0, the truncated or thresholded version θ^nT​r​u​n​c:=θ^n​(Δ1n​X​𝟏{|Δ1n​X|≤vn},…,Δn​Xn​𝟏{|Δnn​X|≤vn})\hat{\theta}^{Trunc}_{n}:=\hat{\theta}_{n}(\Delta_{1}^{n}X\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{1}^{n}X|\leq v_{n}\}},\dots,\Delta_{n}X^{n}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{n}^{n}X|\leq v_{n}\}}) is close enough to θ^C​o​n​t\hat{\theta}^{Cont} so that

1rn​(θ^nTrunc−θ^nCont)=oP​(1).\frac{1}{r_{n}}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n}^{\text{Trunc}}-\hat{\theta}_{n}^{\text{Cont}}\right)=o_{P}(1). (2)

An emblematic example of this approach arises in the estimation of the integrated variance or volatility I​V:=∫0Tσs2​𝑑sIV:=\int_{0}^{T}\sigma^{2}_{s}ds, where one passes from the quantity

I​V^Cont:=∑i=1n(Δin​Xc)2,\widehat{IV}^{\text{Cont}}:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}(\Delta_{i}^{n}X^{c})^{2}, (3)

to its truncated version

I​V^Trunc:=∑i=1n(Δin​X)2​𝟏{|Δin​X|≤vn}.\widehat{IV}^{\text{Trunc}}:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}(\Delta_{i}^{n}X)^{2}{\bf 1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}^{n}X|\leq v_{n}\}}. (4)

By (essentially) employing the steps (1)-(2), it has been established that in the bounded variation case [17, 5], an efficient CLT (see, e.g., [11]) is possible:

n​(I​V^Trunc−I​V)⟶𝒟𝒩​(0,2​∫0Tσs4​𝑑s).\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{IV}^{\text{Trunc}}-IV\right)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mathcal{D}}}{{\longrightarrow}}\mathcal{N}\left(0,2\int_{0}^{T}\sigma_{s}^{4}ds\right).

However, with unbounded-variation jumps, this approach alone falls short. It was proved by [5, 18] that n​(I​V^Trunc−I​V)⟶P∞\sqrt{n}\big(\widehat{IV}^{\text{Trunc}}-IV\big)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle P}}{{\longrightarrow}}\infty in the presence of an infinite variation symmetric stable Lévy process, precisely because the bias of I​V^Trunc\widehat{IV}^{\text{Trunc}} – and thus the difference (I​V^Trunc−I​V^Cont)(\widehat{IV}^{\text{Trunc}}-\widehat{IV}^{\text{Cont}}) – vanishes too slowly.

Two methodological advances have since moved the field forward. The first is due to Jacod and Todorov [12, 13], who proposed an approach for integrated variance estimation based on the empirical characteristic function of the rescaled increments Δin​X/Δn\Delta_{i}^{n}X/\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}, where Δn\Delta_{n} is the time span of the increment. After applying a suitable logarithmic transformation and debiasing procedure, this approach admits a CLT with optimal rate and variance, even in the case of unbounded variation jumps. However, with this method, full (rate and variance) efficiency is attainable only under specific conditions that require either the jump activity index YY to satisfy Y<3/2Y<3/2, or under additional restrictive jump symmetry assumptions. The second major advance was introduced more recently by [3], who showed that a debiasing method similar to [12] applied to the realized truncated variations (4) leads to a fully efficient estimator for any Y≤8/5Y\leq 8/5 without any symmetry conditions.

A natural next question is how these insights extend to the problem of spot volatility estimation. A standard and widely used approach to constructing spot volatility estimators is to apply kernel smoothing to an estimator of integrated variance,

σ^τ2=∫Kb​(t−τ)​𝑑I​V^t,\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau}=\int K_{b}(t-\tau)d\widehat{IV}_{t},

where I​V^t\widehat{IV}_{t} denotes an estimator of I​Vt=∫0tσs2​𝑑sIV_{t}=\int_{0}^{t}\sigma_{s}^{2}ds and Kb​(u):=K​(u/b)/bK_{b}(u):=K(u/b)/b for a chosen kernel KK and a bandwidth b>0b>0. For instance, using the realized quadratic variation I​V^t=∑i=1[n​t](Δin​X)2\widehat{IV}_{t}=\sum_{i=1}^{[nt]}(\Delta_{i}^{n}X)^{2}, this reduces to

σ^τ2=∑i=1nKb​(ti−1−τ)​(Δin​X)2,\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{b}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{i}^{n}X)^{2}, (5)

as proposed in [14, 6].

Spot volatility estimators differ markedly from their integrated volatility counterparts, with their local nature altering the efficiency picture in subtle but important ways: on the one hand, optimal convergence rates are of order n−1/4n^{-1/4} (compared with n−1/2n^{-1/2} in the integrated volatility case); on the other hand, kernel-based estimators enjoy a degree of built-in robustness against jumps, since “large” jumps are relatively rare and are unlikely to fall in a narrow neighborhood of τ\tau where KbK_{b} places most of its mass. For instance, [10, Theorem 13.3.3] shows that in the case of uniform kernels (i.e., K​(u)=𝟏[0,1)​(u)K(u)={\bf 1}_{[0,1)}(u) or K​(u)=𝟏(−1,0]​(u)K(u)={\bf 1}_{(-1,0]}(u)) the estimator (5) admits a rate-optimal CLT even in the case of unbounded variation jumps, provided Y<4/3Y<4/3222The case of jumps of bounded variation corresponds to Y<1Y<1, while the jumps are of unbounded variation when Y>1Y>1.. However, high levels of jump activity can still degrade performance, and the rate becomes suboptimal for Y≥4/3Y\geq 4/3: in general, for any a∈(0,1/2]a\in(0,1/2] such that Y<2/(1+a)Y<2/(1+a), one can find a bandwidth bnb_{n} such that na/2​(σ^τ2−στ2)⟶𝒟𝒩​(0,Vσ)n^{a/2}(\hat{\sigma}_{\tau}^{2}-\sigma_{\tau}^{2})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mathcal{D}}}{{\longrightarrow}}\mathcal{N}(0,V_{\sigma}), which yields a rate that is slower than n−2−Y2​Yn^{-\frac{2-Y}{2Y}}. Thus, if, for instance, Y≤3/2Y\leq 3/2, the rate is slower than n−1/6n^{-1/6}. Surprisingly, following the two-step approach (1)-(2), even when thresholding is applied to (5), i.e.,

σ^τ2=∑i=1nKb​(ti−1−τ)​(Δin​X)2​𝟏{|Δin​X|≤vn},\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{b}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{i}^{n}X)^{2}{\bf 1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}^{n}X|\leq v_{n}\}}, (6)

there is no apparent asymptotic benefit: the optimal rate of n−1/4n^{-1/4} remains attainable only if Y<4/3Y<4/3, and the best possible rate when Y≥4/3Y\geq 4/3 remains bounded by n−2−Y2​Yn^{-\frac{2-Y}{2Y}}, which is strictly slower.

Given these limitations, one may wonder if estimation performance can be improved by modifying the kernel KK. This question was addressed in [8], which extended the approach in [10] to two-sided kernels of unbounded support. Although the convergence rate remains unchanged, they established that the asymptotic variance can be substantially reduced. For example, using the kernel K​(u)=.5​e−|u|K(u)=.5e^{-|u|} leads to an asymptotic variance that is one-quarter of that obtained by a uniform kernel in the suboptimal rate regime (Y≥4/3)(Y\geq 4/3). Moreover, in the optimal rate regime (Y<4/3)(Y<4/3), this kernel was shown to be variance-optimal, highlighting the utility of unbounded kernels in general. However, we note that the results in both [10] and [8] are based on the two-step approach (1)-(2), which we depart from in the present work.

These findings motivate a fundamental question: can one develop methods that attain better rates – possibly optimal – beyond the boundary Y<4/3Y<4/3? A recent step in this direction was taken by [15], who developed a localized variant of the characteristic function approach of [12]. Assuming the infinite-variation jump component is of the form ∫0tχs​𝑑Ls\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s}dL_{s}, where LL is a strictly YY-stable symmetric Lévy process, and while restricting to the class of compactly-supported kernels that are continuously differentiable, they establish that their estimator satisfies

bnΔn​σ^τ2−στ22​στ⟶𝒟𝒩​(0,∫K2​(u)​𝑑u),\sqrt{\frac{b_{n}}{\Delta_{n}}}\frac{\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau}-\sigma^{2}_{\tau}}{\sqrt{2\sigma_{\tau}}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\cal{D}}}{{\longrightarrow}}\mathcal{N}\left(0,\int K^{2}(u)du\right), (7)

for any Y≤3/2Y\leq{}3/2, but with a suboptimal convergence rate (i.e., Δnbn≫n−1/4\sqrt{\frac{\Delta_{n}}{b_{n}}}\gg n^{-1/4}). By applying an additional debiasing step similar to that in [12], they further showed that associated tuning parameters can be chosen so that (7) holds for any Y<2Y<2, however, still with a suboptimal rate and under the jump symmetry condition described above. Consequently, the boundary Y<4/3Y<4/3 has long marked the limit of efficiency in spot volatility estimation, and the regime Y≥4/3Y\geq 4/3 has remained largely underexplored without symmetry assumptions.

In this work, we push this efficiency boundary substantially forward by introducing appropriately debiased versions of the estimator (6). First, by exploiting high-order expansions of the truncated moments of Δi​X\Delta_{i}X, rather than relying on the coarser two-step framework (1)-(2), which does not explicitly account for higher-order bias, we show the estimator (6) actually achieves rate-optimality for any Y≤3/2Y\leq{}3/2 (namely, n1/4​(σ^τ2−στ2)⟶𝒟𝒩​(0,Vσ)n^{1/4}(\hat{\sigma}_{\tau}^{2}-\sigma_{\tau}^{2})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mathcal{D}}}{{\longrightarrow}}\mathcal{N}(0,V_{\sigma})) under standard assumptions and without additional adjustment. Second, by introducing debiasing steps similar to those in [12, 3], we construct fully efficient estimators that cover the range 0<Y<20/110<Y<20/11. This extension is practically relevant, as empirical studies indicate that values of YY are typically between 1.51.5 and 1.81.8 for liquid stocks (see [3] for a brief supporting empirical analysis and further references). Our method stands in sharp contrast to the results in [15], offering rate-optimal estimators over a wider range of YY, broader applicability through more flexible model assumptions, reduced asymptotic variances enabled by the use of unbounded kernels, and simpler estimators that are easier to implement. To validate our results, we perform a comprehensive simulation study and find that our methods significantly outperform those of [15] in terms of both bias and variance over finite samples. Our findings further demonstrate that the advantages of kernels with unbounded support extend to the debiasing framework developed here, providing substantial improvements over widely-used uniform kernels, which are often the default choice in practice, especially in inference problems that require estimation of spot volatility as a preliminary step.

The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 introduces the setting, assumptions, and preliminary results. Section 3 presents the main results and their proofs. Section 4 contains simulations assessing the performance of our estimators. Some additional technical proofs are collected in Appendix A.

2 Setting and background

Consider a 1-dimensional Itô semimartingale X=(Xt)t∈ℝ+X=\big(X_{t}\big)_{t\in\mathbb{R}_{+}} defined on a complete filtered probability space (Ω,ℱ,(ℱ)t∈ℝ+,ℙ)\big(\Omega,\mathscr{F},(\mathscr{F})_{t\in\mathbb{R}_{+}},\mathbb{P}\big) that can be decomposed as

Xt=∫0tbs​𝑑s+∫0tσs​𝑑Ws+∫0tχs−​𝑑Js+∫0t∫δ​(s,z)​𝔭​(d​s,d​z),t∈[0,∞),\displaystyle X_{t}=\int_{0}^{t}b_{s}ds+\int_{0}^{t}\sigma_{s}dW_{s}+\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s^{-}}dJ_{s}+\int_{0}^{t}\int\delta(s,z)\mathfrak{p}(ds,dz),\;\;t\in[0,\infty), (8)

where W:=(Wt)t∈ℝ+W:=(W_{t})_{t\in\mathbb{R}_{+}} is a Wiener process, σ\sigma is an adapted càdlàg process, J:=(Jt)t∈ℝ+J:=(J_{t})_{t\in\mathbb{R}_{+}} is an independent pure-jump Lévy process with Lévy triplet (b,0,v)(b,0,v), and 𝔭\mathfrak{p} is a Poisson random measure on ℝ+×ℝ\mathbb{R}_{+}\times\mathbb{R} with an intensity 𝔮​(d​s,d​z)=d​s⊗λ​(d​z)\mathfrak{q}(ds,dz)=ds\otimes\lambda(dz), such that the λ\lambda is a σ\sigma-finite measure on ℝ\mathbb{R}, possibly dependent with JJ. The Lévy measure vv is assumed to admit a density s:ℝ\{0}→ℝ+s:{\mathbb{R}\backslash\{0\}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+} of the form

s​(x):=d​vd​x:=(C+​𝟏(0,∞)​(x)+C−​𝟏(−∞,0)​(x))​q​(x)​|x|−1−Y.\displaystyle s(x):=\frac{dv}{dx}:=\big(C_{+}\mathbf{1}_{(0,\infty)}(x)+C_{-}\mathbf{1}_{(-\infty,0)}(x)\big)q(x)|x|^{-1-Y}. (9)

We have the following standing assumptions:

Assumption 1.
  1. 1.

    C±>0C_{\pm}>0 and Y∈(0,2)∖{1}Y\in(0,2)\setminus\{1\}.

  2. 2.

    q:ℝ\{0}→ℝ+q:{{\mathbb{R}\backslash\{0\}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+}} is a bounded Borel-measurable function such that:

    1. (a)

      q​(x)→1q(x)\rightarrow 1, as x→0x\rightarrow 0.

    2. (b)

      There exist a±a_{\pm} such that

      ∫01|q​(x)−1−a+​x|​x−Y−1​𝑑x+∫−10|q​(x)−1−a−​x|​|x|−Y−1​𝑑x<∞.\int_{0}^{1}\big|q(x)-1-a_{+}x\big|x^{-Y-1}dx+\int_{-1}^{0}\big|q(x)-1-a_{-}x\big||x|^{-Y-1}dx<\infty. (10)
  3. 3.

    The process χ\chi is given as

    χt=χ0+∫0tbxχ​𝑑s+∫0tΣsχ​𝑑Bs.\chi_{t}=\chi_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}b_{x}^{\chi}ds+\int_{0}^{t}\Sigma_{s}^{\chi}dB_{s}. (11)
  4. 4.

    The processes W,BW,B are standard Brownian motions with correlation d​⟨W,B⟩t=ρt​d​td\langle W,B\rangle_{t}=\rho_{t}dt for an adapted, locally bounded càdlàg process {ρt}t≥0\{\rho_{t}\}_{t\geq 0}. W,BW,B are independent of (J,𝔭)(J,\mathfrak{p}); JJ is independent of σ\sigma.

  5. 5.

    The processes Σχ\Sigma^{\chi}, bb, bχb^{\chi} are càdlàg adapted, and δ\delta is predictable. There exist a sequence {τn}n≥1\{\tau_{n}\}_{n\geq 1} of stopping times increasing to infinity, nonnegative λ​(d​z)\lambda(dz)-integrable function HH and a positive sequence {Mn}n≥1\{M_{n}\}_{n\geq 1} such that

    t≤τn⇒{|σt|+|bt|+|btχ|+|Σtχ|≤Mn,(|δ​(t,z)|∧1)r≤Mn​H​(z),t\leq\tau_{n}\Rightarrow\begin{cases}|\sigma_{t}|+|b_{t}|+|b_{t}^{\chi}|+|\Sigma_{t}^{\chi}|\leq M_{n},\\ ({|\delta(t,z)|}\wedge 1)^{{r}}\leq M_{n}{H(z)},\end{cases}

    for some r∈[0,1∧Y){r}\in[0,1\wedge Y).

  6. 6.

    The spot variance process ct:=σt2c_{t}:=\sigma_{t}^{2} is assumed to follow the dynamics:

    ct=c0+∫0tμ~s​𝑑s+∫0tσ~s​𝑑Bs,\displaystyle c_{t}=c_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\tilde{\mu}_{s}ds+\int_{0}^{t}\tilde{\sigma}_{s}dB_{s}, (12)

    where B:=(Bt)t≥0B:=(B_{t})_{t\geq 0} is as in point 3 above. Here {μ~}t≥0\{\tilde{\mu}\}_{t\geq 0} and (σ~t)t≥0(\tilde{\sigma}_{t})_{t\geq 0} are adapted càdlàg locally bounded processes.

Remark 1.

The conditions above are essentially the same as those in [3]. [15] considered a similar but more restrictive component of unbounded variation by taking JJ to be a symmetric strictly stable Lévy process, while here we considered a type of tempered stable Lévy process. The most technical (but still relatively mild) condition is that in (10), which is used to apply a density transformation or change of probability measure under which the process JJ becomes stable. We refer to [3] for further details.

We assume we have at our disposal nn evenly-spaced discrete observations XtiX_{t_{i}} during a fixed time interval [0,T][0,T]. For simplicity, we further assume T=1T=1 and, thus, ti=i/nt_{i}=i/n. Denote Δn=1/n\Delta_{n}=1/n, ℱin:=ℱti\mathcal{F}_{i}^{n}:=\mathcal{F}_{t_{i}}, and Δin​A=Ai​Δn−A(i−1)​Δn\Delta^{n}_{i}A=A_{i\Delta_{n}}-A_{(i-1)\Delta_{n}} for any process AA, where we often omit the superscript nn. Our estimation target is cτ=στ2c_{\tau}=\sigma_{\tau}^{2} for a fixed time τ∈(0,T)\tau\in(0,T). We consider the spot volatility estimator

c^n​(mn,vn):=∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​(Δin​X)2​𝟏{|Δin​X|≤vn}Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ),\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}):=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{i}^{n}X)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}^{n}X|\leq v_{n}\}}}{\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}}, (13)

where KK is a kernel function, and mnm_{n} controls the bandwidth bn:=mn​Δnb_{n}:=m_{n}\Delta_{n} such that mn→∞m_{n}\rightarrow\infty and mn​Δn→0m_{n}\Delta_{n}\rightarrow 0, and Kb​(x):=K​(x/b)/bK_{b}(x):=K(x/b)/b. We assume the following conditions on KK, which are standard:

Assumption 2.

The kernel function K:ℝ→[0,∞)K:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow[0,\infty) is bounded and Lipschitz and piecewise C1C^{1} on (−∞,∞)(-\infty,\infty) such that ∫K​(x)​𝑑x=1\int K(x)dx=1, ∫|K​(x)​x|​𝑑x<∞\int|K(x)x|dx<\infty, ∫|K′​(x)|​𝑑x<∞\int|K^{\prime}(x)|dx<\infty, and K​(y)​y2→0K(y)y^{2}\rightarrow 0 as |y|→∞|y|\rightarrow\infty.

The estimator (13) without the denominator factor, truncation, or any debiasing was studied in [6] and [14] (see also additional references in the introduction). The denominator, motivated by the standard Nadarayan-Watson nonparametric regression estimator, and noted in passing in [14], serves a dual role: it provides edge correction in finite samples and simplifies several proofs, notably leading to more relaxed technical assumptions in the optimal bandwidth regime (see Remark 2 below). In contrast, when the denominator is omitted, our results remain valid, but stricter conditions on the bandwidth bn=mn​Δnb_{n}=m_{n}\Delta_{n} and its relationship with YY are required; however, in the suboptimal rate regime (see Remark 2, case (ii), below), the denominator can be dispensed of entirely without any loss of generality. The truncated version in (13) was studied in [7] and [8], also without debiasing. Finally, Assumption 2 permits kernels of unbounded support, which, as discussed in the introduction, enables estimators that are more variance efficient in both the optimal and suboptimal convergence regimes.

Notation: Throughout, An≲BnA_{n}\lesssim B_{n} and an≪bna_{n}\ll b_{n} mean An=OP​(Bn)A_{n}=O_{P}(B_{n}) and an=o​(bn)a_{n}=o(b_{n}), respectively. For any process VV, when unambiguous we write Δi​V\Delta_{i}V in place of Δin​V\Delta_{i}^{n}V.

3 Main results

The following moment expansions play key roles in our analysis. The proofs are based on arguments in analogous results in [3] (see Lemmas 2, 3, 4 and 5 therein) and are given in Appendix A.1.5 for completeness.

Proposition 1.

Suppose that Y∈(0,2)∖{1}Y\in(0,2)\setminus\{1\}. Let Δn12−s≪vn≪Δn14−Y\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}-s}\ll v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4-Y}} for a fixed s∈(0,1/2)s\in(0,1/2). Then, the following statements hold:

  1. 1.

    For any integer p≥1p\geq 1, we have

    𝔼​((Δi​X)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}|ℱi−1)=(2​p−1)!!​σti−12​p​Δnp+Cp,i​Δn​vn2​p−Y+oP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)+oP​(Δnp),\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\big((\Delta_{i}X)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)=(2{p}-1)!!\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2{p}}\Delta_{n}^{p}+C_{{p},i}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2{p}-Y}+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2{p}-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{p}), (14)

    where Cp,i:=(C++C−)​|χti−1|Y2​p−YC_{p,i}:=\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})|\chi_{t_{i-1}}|^{Y}}{2p-Y}.

  2. 2.

    Furthermore, if p=1p=1, the following high-order expansion holds:

    𝔼​((Δi​X)2​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}|ℱi−1)=σti−12​Δn+C1,i​Δn​vn2−Y+D1,i​Δn2​vn−Y+OP​(Δn3​vn−2−Y)+oP​(Δn5/4),\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\big((\Delta_{i}X)^{2{}}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)=\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Delta_{n}+C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y}+D_{1,i}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-Y}+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}), (15)

    where D1,i=(C++C−)​(Y+1)​(Y+2)2​Y​σti−12​|χti−1|YD_{1,i}=\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})(Y+1)(Y+2)}{2Y}\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}|\chi_{t_{i-1}}|^{Y}. Additionally, for any ζ>1\zeta>1, we have

    𝔼​((Δi​X)2​𝟏{vn<|Δi​X|≤ζ​vn}|ℱi−1)\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\big((\Delta_{i}X)^{2{}}\mathbf{1}_{\{v_{n}<|\Delta_{i}X|\leq\zeta v_{n}\}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big) =C1,i​Δn​(ζ2−Y−1)​vn2−Y+D1,i​Δn2​(ζ−Y−1)​vn−Y\displaystyle=C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}(\zeta^{2-Y}-1)v_{n}^{2-Y}+D_{1,i}\Delta_{n}^{2}(\zeta^{-Y}-1)v_{n}^{-Y} (16)
    +OP​(Δn3​vn−2−Y)+oP​(Δn34​vn4−Y2).\displaystyle\quad+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}).
  3. 3.

    For any p>1p>1 (not necessarily an integer), we have

    𝔼​(|Δi​X|2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}|ℱi−1)=OP​(σti−12​p​Δnp)+OP​(Cp,ti−1​Δn​vn2​p−Y).\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\big(|\Delta_{i}X|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2{p}}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(C_{{p},t_{i-1}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2{p}-Y}). (17)

To analyze the asymptotic behavior of the estimator c^n​(mn,vn)\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) defined in Eq. (13), we consider the following decomposition:

c^n​(mn,vn)\displaystyle\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) =(c^n​(mn,vn)−Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ))\displaystyle=\left(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-\frac{\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}}{\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}}\right)
+(Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ))\displaystyle\quad+\left(\frac{\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}}{\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}}\right)
=:c^n,1(mn,vn)+c^n,2(mn).\displaystyle=:\hat{c}_{n,1}(m_{n},v_{n})+\hat{c}_{n,2}(m_{n}). (18)

Our next result is central to our analysis and underpins our main debiasing procedure. It establishes the joint asymptotic behavior of the terms in (3), accounting for appropriate bias terms, and provides the framework for separating qualitatively distinct asymptotic regimes for mnm_{n}. In addition, on its own, it yields feasible CLTs for c^n​(mn,vn)\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) in certain settings that sharpen existing results in the literature (see Remark 2).

Theorem 1.

Suppose that Δnβ≪vn≪Δnβ′\Delta_{n}^{\beta}\ll v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\beta^{\prime}} with 14−Y<β′<β<12\frac{1}{4-Y}<\beta^{\prime}<\beta<\frac{1}{2}, log​(n)≪mn≪Δn−4​vn4+2​Y\sqrt{\mathrm{log}(n)}\ll m_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-4}v_{n}^{4+2Y}, and mn=O​(Δn−12)m_{n}=O(\Delta_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2}}). Let

Z~n​(mn,vn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) :=mn​(c^n,1​(mn,vn)−A​(vn,mn)),\displaystyle:=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\hat{c}_{n,1}(m_{n},v_{n})-A(v_{n},m_{n})\Big),
Z~n′​(mn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}_{n}^{\prime}(m_{n}) :=1mn​Δn​(c^n,2​(mn)−στ2),\displaystyle:=\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\Big(\hat{c}_{n,2}(m_{n})-\sigma^{2}_{\tau}\Big),

where, using the notation in (15),

A​(vn,mn):=∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​C1,i​Δn​vn2−YΔn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)+∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​D1,i​Δn2​vn−YΔn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ).\displaystyle{A(v_{n},m_{n}):=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau){C_{1,i}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}+\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau){D_{1,i}}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-Y}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}.} (19)

Then, under Assumptions 1 and 2, as n→∞n\rightarrow\infty,

(Z~n​(mn,vn),Z~n′​(mn))→s​t(Z1,Z2),\displaystyle(\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}),\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n}))\xrightarrow{st}\mathcal{(}Z_{1},Z_{2}), (20)

where Z1∼N​(0,2​στ4​∫K2​(x)​𝑑x)Z_{1}\sim N\big(0,2\sigma_{\tau}^{4}\int K^{2}(x)dx\big) and Z2∼N​(0,σ~τ2​∫L2​(t)​𝑑t)Z_{2}\sim N(0,{\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau}}\int L^{2}(t)dt) with L​(t)=∫t∞K​(u)​𝑑u​𝟏t≥0−∫−∞tK​(u)​𝑑u​𝟏t<0L(t)=\int_{t}^{\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t\geq 0}-\int^{t}_{-\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t<0}, and Z1Z_{1} and Z2Z_{2} are independent.

Remark 2.

Taking mn→∞m_{n}\to\infty at different rates alters the balance of the errors appearing on the right-hand side of (20). Three distinct regimes can be distinguished: (i) mn​Δn→θ∈(0,∞)m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to\theta\in(0,\infty), (ii) mn​Δn→0m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to 0, and (iii) mn​Δn→∞m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to\infty, which we remark on below.

Case (i): mn​Δn→θ∈(0,∞)m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to\theta\in(0,\infty). In this regime, the orders of mn\sqrt{m_{n}} and 1/mn​Δn1/\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}} match, in which case Theorem 1 gives

Δn−1/4​(c^n​(mn,vn)−A​(vn,mn)−στ2)→s​tθ−1/2​Z1+θ1/2​Z2,\Delta_{n}^{-1/4}\left(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-A(v_{n},m_{n})-\sigma_{\tau}^{2}\right)\xrightarrow{st}\theta^{-1/2}Z_{1}+\theta^{1/2}Z_{2}, (21)

or, equivalently,

mn​(c^n​(mn,vn)−A​(vn,mn)−στ2)→s​tZ1+θ​Z2.\sqrt{m_{n}}\left(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-A(v_{n},m_{n})-\sigma_{\tau}^{2}\right)\xrightarrow{st}Z_{1}+\theta Z_{2}. (22)

Note that the bias term A​(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}) is OP​(vn2−Y)O_{P}(v_{n}^{2-Y}). Thus, if mn​vn2−Y≪1\sqrt{m_{n}}v_{n}^{2-Y}\ll 1, then (21) and (22) remain true even with the term A​(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}) omitted, in which case we obtain a valid feasible CLT for the estimation error c^n​(mn,vn)−στ2\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-\sigma_{\tau}^{2} with convergence rate Δn1/4\Delta_{n}^{1/4} (which is optimal). While the condition mn​vn2−Y≪1\sqrt{m_{n}}v_{n}^{2-Y}\ll 1 can be met in principle by taking small enough vnv_{n}, Theorem 1 additionally requires vn≫Δn1/2v_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{1/2}, and thus implicitly Δn−1/4​Δn(2−Y)/2≪1\Delta_{n}^{-1/4}\Delta_{n}^{(2-Y)/2}\ll 1, which can happen only if Y<3/2Y<3/2. Nevertheless, this result significantly improves upon [8] (and also [10]), where a rate-optimal CLT is shown to be valid only when Y<4/3Y<4/3. Theorem 1 also yields stronger results than the characteristic function approach taken in [15], in which a similar CLT is is shown to be valid, under substantially more restrictive model assumptions333For instance, they assume that the process JJ in (8) is a symmetric stable Lévy process, for Y<3/2Y<3/2 at a convergent rate strictly slower than Δn1/4\Delta_{n}^{1/4} (due to an assumption that mn​Δn→0m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to{}0).

Further, under case (i), the conditions on vnv_{n} take the form Δnβ∨Δn74​Y+8≪vn≪Δnβ′\Delta_{n}^{\beta}\vee\Delta_{n}^{\frac{7}{4Y+8}}\ll v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\beta^{\prime}} (14−Y<β′<β<12\frac{1}{4-Y}<\beta^{\prime}<\beta<\frac{1}{2}), which can hold only if 74​Y+8>14−Y\frac{7}{4Y+8}>\frac{1}{4-Y}, which requires Y<2011Y<\frac{20}{11}. Thus, this rate-optimal case (i) covers nearly the entire admissible range of YY observed in applications, and ultimately underpins our feasible efficient CLT in this range (Theorem 3).

Case (ii): mn​Δn→0m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to 0. This regime corresponds to setting θ=0\theta=0 in (22). Indeed,

mn​(c^n​(mn,vn)−A​(vn,mn)−στ2)=Z~n​(mn,vn)+mn​Δn​Z~n′​(mn,vn),\sqrt{m_{n}}\left(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-A(v_{n},m_{n})-\sigma_{\tau}^{2}\right)=\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})+m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}), (23)

and, from (20), the first term above converges to Z1Z_{1}, while the second is oP​(1)o_{P}(1). In this case, the attained convergence rate, 1/mn1/\sqrt{m_{n}}, is suboptimal, i.e., slower than the Δ1/4\Delta^{1/4} rate achieved when θ∈(0,∞)\theta\in(0,\infty). However, this asymptotic regime has the practical advantage that any eventual estimation of the volatility-of-volatiltity σ~τ2\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}^{2} is not needed when constructing confidence intervals, since Z2Z_{2} is absent from the limit. If we also require mn​vn2−Y≪1\sqrt{m_{n}}v_{n}^{2-Y}\ll 1, then the bias A​(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}) can be omitted in (23) leading to a feasible CLT for c^n​(mn,vn)\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) centered at στ2\sigma_{\tau}^{2}. Under this constraint, the condition vn≫Δn12v_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}} and the asymptotic condition of case (ii) together imply that the convergence rate mn−1/2m_{n}^{-1/2} must be strictly slower than Δn14∧2−Y2\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4}\wedge\frac{2-Y}{2}}, yielding a convergence rate that can be taken arbitrarily close to Δn1/4\Delta_{n}^{1/4} when Y<3/2Y<3/2 but deteriorates as YY increases to 22.

Case (iii): mn​Δn→∞m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to\infty. Though technically excluded from our hypotheses, our results can also cover the regime mn​Δn→∞m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to\infty, but at the expense of an upper bound of Y<8/5Y<8/5 in the jump activity index. In this setting, the attained convergence rate is mn​Δn\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}, which is not as fast as the analogous rates when θ∈[0,∞)\theta\in[0,\infty).

Remark 3.

Beyond finite-sample edge correction, the denominator in (13) (which converges to 1) relaxes the technical conditions required for our results; without it, additional restrictions on YY and mnm_{n} are necessary. Specifically, define c~n​(mn,vn):=∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​(Δi​X)2​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}{\tilde{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})}:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}, and let Z~n​(mn,vn)\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}), Z~n′​(mn)\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n}), and A​(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}) denote the corresponding analogs without the denominator. Then the limit (20) still holds under the hypotheses of Theorem 1, provided also that mn≫Δn−1/3m_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{-1/3}. Under this additional condition on mnm_{n}, (22) remains valid for Y<20/11Y<20/11 when mn​Δn→θ∈(0,∞)m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to\theta\in(0,\infty). However, a much more substantive difference arises when mn​Δn→0m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\to 0: if we also impose mn​vn2−Y≪1\sqrt{m_{n}}v_{n}^{2-Y}\ll 1 to obtain a feasible CLT (as discussed in Remark 2), the constraint becomes Δn−1/3≪mn≪vn2​(Y−2)≪ΔnY−2\Delta_{n}^{-1/3}\ll m_{n}\ll v_{n}^{2(Y-2)}\ll\Delta_{n}^{Y-2}, which can only be satisfied if Y<5/3Y<5/3, illustrating the benefit of including the denominator factor in (13).

Proof of Theorem 1.

Denote

Yi\displaystyle Y_{i} :=mn​Kmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​(Δi​X)2​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn},\displaystyle:=\sqrt{m_{n}}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}},
Yi′\displaystyle Y^{\prime}_{i} :=Δnmn​Δn×{0,if ​i=1,−(∑l=1i−1Kmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ))​Δi​B,if ​2≤i≤⌈τ/Δn⌉,(∑l=inKmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ))​Δi​B,if ​⌈τ/Δn⌉<i≤n.\displaystyle:=\frac{\Delta_{n}}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\times\left\{\begin{aligned} &0,\;&\text{if }i=1,\\ -&\Big(\sum_{l=1}^{i-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\Delta_{i}B,\;&\text{if }2\leq i\leq\lceil\tau/\Delta_{n}\rceil,\\ &\Big(\sum_{l=i}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\Delta_{i}B,\;&\text{if }\lceil\tau/\Delta_{n}\rceil<i\leq n.\end{aligned}\right.

Consider the following decompositions:

Z~n​(mn,vn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) =(∑i=1nYiΔn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)−∑i=1n𝔼​(Yi|ℱi−1)Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ))\displaystyle=\Big(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}\Big)
+(∑i=1n𝔼​(Yi|ℱi−1)Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)−mn​Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)​σti−12−mn​A​(vn,mn))\displaystyle\qquad+\Big(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}-\sqrt{m_{n}}A(v_{n},m_{n})\Big)
=:T1+T2,\displaystyle=:T_{1}+T_{2}, (24)

and

Z~n′​(mn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n}) =σ~τ​∑i=1nYi′Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)+(Z~n′​(mn)−σ~τ​∑i=1nYi′Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ))\displaystyle=\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}^{\prime}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}+\Big({\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n})}-\frac{\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}^{\prime}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}\Big)
=σ~τ​∑i=1nYi′Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)\displaystyle=\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}^{\prime}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}
+(Δnmn​Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​(σti−12−στ2)Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)−σ~τ​∑i=1nYi′Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ))\displaystyle\quad+\Big(\frac{\Delta_{n}}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}-\sigma^{2}_{\tau})}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}^{\prime}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}\Big)
=:T3+T4.\displaystyle=:T_{3}+T_{4}. (25)

We now proceed to show (T1,T3)→s​t(Z1,σ~τ​Z2)(T_{1},T_{3})\xrightarrow{st}(Z_{1},\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}Z_{2}) by verifying the conditions of Theorem 2.2.15 in [10], and in addition that T2T_{2} and T4T_{4} are asymptotically negligible.

a) We start with T3T_{3}. Clearly, 𝔼​(Yi′|ℱi−1)=0\mathbb{E}(Y^{\prime}_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})=0 and, using the moment formula for Gaussian distributions and Lemma 3.1 in [9], we have

∑i=1nVar​(Yi′|ℱi−1)\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\mathrm{Var}(Y^{\prime}_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})} =Δn2mn​Δn​∑i=1n((−∑l=1i−1Kmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ))2​Δn​𝟏τ≥ti+(∑l=inKmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ))2​Δn​𝟏τ<ti)\displaystyle=\frac{\Delta_{n}^{2}}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Big(-\sum_{l=1}^{i-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)^{2}\Delta_{n}\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq t_{i}}+\Big(\sum_{l=i}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)^{2}\Delta_{n}\mathbf{1}_{\tau<t_{i}}\right)
=1mn​Δn​∫01(∫v1Kmn​Δn​(s−τ)​𝑑s​𝟏τ≥v−∫0vKmn​Δn​(s−τ)​𝑑s​𝟏τ<v)2​𝑑v+oP​(1)\displaystyle\quad=\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\int_{0}^{1}\Big(\int_{{v}}^{1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}({s}-\tau)ds\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq{v}}-\int^{{v}}_{0}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}({s}-\tau)ds\mathbf{1}_{\tau<{v}}\Big)^{2}dv+o_{P}(1)
→𝑃∫(∫t∞K​(u)​𝑑u​𝟏t≥0−∫−∞tK​(u)​𝑑u​𝟏t<0)2​𝑑t,\displaystyle\quad\xrightarrow{P}\int\Big(\int_{t}^{\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t\geq 0}-\int^{t}_{-\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t<0}\Big)^{2}dt,

and

∑i=1n𝔼​(Y′i4|ℱi−1)\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}({Y^{\prime}}_{i}^{4}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) =3​Δn4mn2​Δn2​∑i=1n((∑l=1i−1Kmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ))4​Δn2​𝟏τ≥ti+(∑l=inKmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ))4​Δn2​𝟏τ<i)\displaystyle=\frac{3\Delta_{n}^{4}}{m_{n}^{2}\Delta_{n}^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Big(\sum_{l=1}^{i-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)^{4}\Delta_{n}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq t_{i}}+\Big(\sum_{l=i}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)^{4}\Delta_{n}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\tau<i}\right)
=3mn​∫(∫t∞K​(u)​𝑑u​𝟏t≥0−∫−∞tK​(u)​𝑑u​𝟏t<0)4​𝑑t+oP​(1)→𝑃0.\displaystyle\quad=\frac{3}{m_{n}}\int\left(\int_{t}^{\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t\geq 0}-\int^{t}_{-\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t<0}\right)^{4}dt+o_{P}(1)\xrightarrow{P}0.

On the other hand, by Assumption 2 and Lemma 3.1 in [9], with f≡1f\equiv 1 and m=1m=1 therein, we have

Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)−1=O​(mn−1),\displaystyle\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)-1={O(m_{n}^{-1})}, (26)

which vanishes as n→∞n\rightarrow\infty. Therefore,

∑i=1nVar​(Yi′|ℱi−1)(Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ))2→𝑃∫(∫t∞K​(u)​𝑑u​𝟏t≥0−∫−∞tK​(u)​𝑑u​𝟏t<0)2​𝑑t,\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\mathrm{Var}(Y^{\prime}_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}}{{\big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)\big)^{2}}}\xrightarrow{P}\int\Big(\int_{t}^{\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t\geq 0}-\int^{t}_{-\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t<0}\Big)^{2}dt,
and ​∑i=1n𝔼​(Y′i4|ℱi−1)(Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ))4→0.\displaystyle\text{and }\;\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}({Y^{\prime}}_{i}^{4}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)\big)^{4}}\rightarrow 0.

To conclude T3→s​tσ~τ​Z2T_{3}\xrightarrow{st}\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}Z_{2}, from Theorem 2.2.15 in [10] it suffices to show the following technical condition:

∑i=1n𝔼i−1​(Yi′​Δi​M)→0,\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(Y^{\prime}_{i}\Delta_{i}M\big)\rightarrow 0, (27)

where 𝔼i−1(⋅)=𝔼(⋅|ℱi−1)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}(\cdot|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) and MM is either WW or BB or is in the set 𝒩\mathcal{N} containing all bounded martingales orthogonal to WW and BB. When M=BM=B, we have

∑i=1n𝔼​(Yi′​Δi​B|ℱi−1)\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y^{\prime}_{i}\Delta_{i}B|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) =Δnmn​Δn​∑i=1n(−(∑l=1i−1Kmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ))​Δn​𝟏τ≥ti+(∑l=inKmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ))​Δn​𝟏τ<ti)\displaystyle=\frac{\Delta_{n}}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(-\Big(\sum_{l=1}^{i-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\Delta_{n}\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq t_{i}}+\Big(\sum_{l=i}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\Delta_{n}\mathbf{1}_{\tau<{t_{i}}}\right)
=1mn​Δn​∫01(∫v1Kmn​Δn​(s−τ)​𝑑s​𝟏τ≥v−∫0vKmn​Δn​(s−τ)​𝑑s​𝟏τ<v)​𝑑v+o​(1)\displaystyle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\int_{0}^{1}\Big(\int_{{v}}^{1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}({s}-{\tau})ds\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq{v}}-\int^{{v}}_{0}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(s-{\tau})ds\mathbf{1}_{\tau<{v}}\Big)d{v}+o(1)
=mn​Δn​∫(∫t∞K​(u)​𝑑u​𝟏t≥0−∫−∞tK​(u)​𝑑u​𝟏t<0)​𝑑t+o​(1)→𝑃0.\displaystyle=\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\int\Big(\int_{t}^{\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t\geq 0}-\int^{t}_{-\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{t<0}\Big)d{t}+o(1)\xrightarrow{P}0.

When M∈𝒩M\in\mathcal{N} or M=WM=W, since 𝔼​(Δi​B​Δi​W|ℱi−1)=OP​(Δn)\mathbb{E}(\Delta_{i}B\Delta_{i}W|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}), similar to the case with M=BM=B, we obtain

∑i=1n𝔼​(Yi′​Δi​M|ℱi−1)≲1mn​Δn​∫(∫t∞K​(u)​𝑑u​𝟏τ≥0−∫−∞tK​(u)​𝑑u​𝟏τ<0)​𝑑t→0.\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}\big(Y^{\prime}_{i}\Delta_{i}M|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)\lesssim\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\int\Big(\int_{t}^{\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq 0}-\int^{t}_{-\infty}K(u)du\mathbf{1}_{\tau<0}\Big)dt\rightarrow 0.

b) Next, we work with the term T4T_{4} of (3). Let i′∈{1,…,n}i^{\prime}\in\{1,\dots,n\} be such that τ∈(ti′−1,ti′]\tau\in(t_{i^{\prime}-1},t_{i^{\prime}}]. Notice that

∑i=1nYi′\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}Y_{i}^{\prime} =−∑l=1i′−1(∑i=l+1i′Δi​B)​Kmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ)+∑l=i′+1n(∑i=i′+1lΔi​B)​Kmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ)\displaystyle=-\sum_{l=1}^{i^{\prime}-1}\big(\sum_{i=l+1}^{i^{\prime}}\Delta_{i}B\big)K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)+\sum_{l=i^{\prime}+1}^{n}\big(\sum_{i=i^{\prime}+1}^{l}\Delta_{i}B\big)K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau) (28)
=∑l=1i′−1Kmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ)​(Btl−Bti′)+∑l=i′+1nKmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ)​(Btl−Bti′).\displaystyle=\sum_{l=1}^{i^{\prime}-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)(B_{t_{l}}-B_{t_{i^{\prime}}})+\sum_{l=i^{\prime}+1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)(B_{t_{l}}-B_{t_{i^{\prime}}}). (29)

In light of (26), we can then write

|T4|\displaystyle|T_{4}| ≲|1mn​Δn​(Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​(∫τti−1(σ~s−σ~τ)​𝑑Bs+∫τti−1μ~s​𝑑s))|\displaystyle\lesssim\Big|\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\Big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(\int_{\tau}^{t_{i-1}}(\tilde{\sigma}_{s}-\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau})dB_{s}+\int_{\tau}^{t_{i-1}}\tilde{\mu}_{s}ds\big)\Big)\Big|
+|1mn​ΔnΔn∑i=1nKmn​Δn(ti−1−τ)(∫ti−1tiσ~τdBs+∫τti′σ~τdBs)|=:|T4,1|+|T4,2|.\displaystyle\quad+\Big|\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\Big(\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}dB_{s}+\int_{\tau}^{t_{i^{\prime}}}\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}dB_{s}\Big)\Big|=:|T_{4,1}|+|T_{4,2}|. (30)

Since |Bti′−Bτ|=OP​(Δn1/2)|B_{t_{i^{\prime}}}-B_{\tau}|=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{1/2}) and supi|Bti−Bti−1|=OP​(Δn1/2​log​(n)1/2)\sup_{i}|B_{t_{i}}-B_{t_{i-1}}|=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\mathrm{log}(n)^{1/2}), the second term T4,2T_{4,2} has order OP​(Δn​log​(n)mn​Δn)O_{P}(\frac{\sqrt{\Delta_{n}\mathrm{log}(n)}}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}) and vanishes given that mn≫log​(n)m_{n}\gg\sqrt{\mathrm{log}(n)} as n→∞n\rightarrow\infty. We just need to worry about the first term. Let

ηi:=∫τti−1(σ~τ−σ~s)​𝑑Bs+∫τti−1μ~s​𝑑s,andρ​(i):=1ti−1−τ​𝔼​(∫τti−1|σ~s−σ~τ|2​𝑑s).\eta_{i}:=\int_{\tau}^{t_{i-1}}(\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}-\tilde{\sigma}_{s})dB_{s}+\int_{\tau}^{t_{i-1}}\tilde{\mu}_{s}ds,\quad\text{and}\quad\quad\rho(i):=\frac{1}{t_{i-1}-\tau}\mathbb{E}\Big(\int_{\tau}^{t_{i-1}}|\tilde{\sigma}_{s}-\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}|^{2}ds\Big).

Note that, following the same argument as in the proof of (13.3.37) for j=6j=6 in [10] (see also the proof of (A.6) for l=4l=4 in [8]), and using that σ~\tilde{\sigma} is càdlàg and bounded, for any positive sequence Nn→∞N_{n}\rightarrow\infty with mn​Δn​Nn→0m_{n}\Delta_{n}N_{n}\rightarrow 0 as n→∞n\rightarrow\infty, it holds that

𝔼​(ηi2​1i∈ℐn)≤c​|ti−1−τ|​ρ​(i)andsupi∈ℐnρ​(i)→0,\mathbb{E}(\eta_{i}^{2}1_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}})\leq c|t_{i-1}-\tau|\rho(i)\quad\text{and}\quad\sup_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}}\rho(i)\rightarrow 0,

where ℐn:={i∈{1,…,n}:ti∈(τ−N​mn​Δn,τ+N​mn​Δn)}\mathcal{I}_{n}:=\{i\in\{1,\dots,n\}:t_{i}\in(\tau-Nm_{n}\Delta_{n},\tau+Nm_{n}\Delta_{n})\}. Additionally, using the Itô isometry and boundedness of σ~\tilde{\sigma} and μ~\tilde{\mu}, it is easily seen that 𝔼​ηi2≲|τ−ti|\mathbb{E}\eta_{i}^{2}\lesssim|\tau-t_{i}| for any ii. Thus,

𝔼​|T4,1|\displaystyle\mathbb{E}|T_{4,1}| ≲1mn​Δn​(Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​(𝟏i∈ℐn+𝟏i∉ℐn)​𝔼​ηi2)\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\Big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau){\left(\mathbf{1}_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}}+\mathbf{1}_{i\notin\mathcal{I}_{n}}\right)}\sqrt{\mathbb{E}\eta_{i}^{2}}\Big)
≲1mn​Δn​(Δn​∑i=1n1mn​Δn​𝟏i∈ℐn​|ti−1−τ|​ρi)\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\Big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\mathbf{1}_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}}\sqrt{|t_{i-1}-\tau|\rho_{i}}\Big)
+1mn​Δn(Δn∑i=1nKmn​Δn(ti−1−τ))𝟏i∉ℐn|ti−1−τ|)\displaystyle\quad+\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\Big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau))\mathbf{1}_{i\notin\mathcal{I}_{n}}\sqrt{|t_{i-1}-\tau|}\Big)
≲mn​Δnmn​Δn​mn​ΔnNnNn​mn​Δn​supi∈ℐnρi+∫|u|>NK(u)|u|du).\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}m_{n}\Delta_{n}}N_{n}\sqrt{N_{n}m_{n}\Delta_{n}\sup_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}}\rho_{i}}+\int_{|u|>N}K(u)\sqrt{|u|}du\Big).

Then, we see that T4=oP​(1)T_{4}=o_{P}(1) by taking Nn→∞N_{n}\to\infty slow enough such that Nn3/2​supi∈ℐnρi→0N_{n}^{3/2}\sup_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}}\rho_{i}\rightarrow 0 (such an NnN_{n} is possible since as NnN_{n} diverges more slowly, the quantity supi∈ℐnρi\sup_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{n}}\rho_{i} vanishes at a faster rate). Now, we conclude

1mn​Δn​Z~n′​(mn)→N​(0,σ~τ2​L2​(t)).\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n})\rightarrow N\big(0,\tilde{\sigma}_{\tau}^{2}L^{2}(t)\big).

c) We now proceed to consider T1T_{1} and T2T_{2} of Eq. (3). First, by Proposition 1, for any p>2p>2, we can write

𝔼​(Yi|ℱi−1)\displaystyle\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) =mn​Kmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​(σti−12​Δn+C1,i​Δn​vn2−Y+D1,i​Δn2​vn−Y+OP​(Δn3​vn−2−Y)+oP​(Δn5/4)),\displaystyle=\sqrt{m_{n}}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Delta_{n}+C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y}+D_{1,i}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-Y}+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4})\big),
𝔼​(Yip|ℱi−1)\displaystyle\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}^{p}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) ≲mnp/2​Kmn​Δnp​(ti−1−τ)​(Δnp​σti−12​p+Δn​vn2​p−Y),\displaystyle\lesssim m_{n}^{p/2}K^{p}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(\Delta_{n}^{p}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}+\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}\big),
Var​(Yi|ℱi−1)\displaystyle\mathrm{Var}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) =mn​Kmn​Δn2​(ti−1−τ)​(2​Δn2​σti−14+OP​(Δn2​vn2−Y)+O​(Δn​vn4−Y))\displaystyle=m_{n}K^{2}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(2\Delta_{n}^{2}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{4}+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2-Y})+O(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y})\big)
=mn​Kmn​Δn2​(ti−1−τ)​(2​Δn2​σti−14+OP​(Δn​vn4−Y)).\displaystyle=m_{n}K^{2}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(2\Delta_{n}^{2}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{4}+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y})\big).

Then,

s1​n2:=∑i=1nVar​(Yi|ℱi−1)=mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn2​(ti−1−τ)​(2​Δn2​σti−14+OP​(Δn​vn4−Y)).s_{1n}^{2}:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathrm{Var}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})=m_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K^{2}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(2\Delta_{n}^{2}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{4}+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y})\big).

Given vn≪Δn14−Yv_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4-Y}} and (26), we obtain

s1​n2(Δn​∑j=1Kmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ))2→2​στ4​∫K2​(x)​𝑑x.\displaystyle\frac{s_{1n}^{2}}{(\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau))^{2}}\rightarrow 2\sigma^{4}_{\tau}\int K^{2}(x)dx.

Moreover, we have

∑i=1n𝔼​(Yip|ℱi−1)≲1mnp/2−1​Δnp−1​∫Kp​(x)​𝑑x​(στ2​p​Δnp−1+OP​(vn2​p−Y)).\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}^{p}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})\lesssim\frac{1}{m_{n}^{p/2-1}\Delta_{n}^{p-1}}\int K^{p}(x)dx(\sigma^{2p}_{\tau}\Delta_{n}^{p-1}+O_{P}(v_{n}^{2p-Y})).

If we rewrite p=(2​ℓ+1)/ℓp=(2\ell+1)/\ell for some ℓ>0{\ell}>0, the right-hand side of the above inequality vanishes if and only if

mn−12​ℓ​Δn−1−1ℓ​vn4​ℓ+2ℓ−Y=((Δn−1​vn4−Y)ℓ​(mn−12​Δn−1​vn2))1ℓ=Δn−1​vn4−Y​(mn−12​Δn−1​vn2)1ℓ→0.\displaystyle m_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2\ell}}\Delta_{n}^{-1-\frac{1}{\ell}}v_{n}^{\frac{4\ell+2}{\ell}-Y}=\Big((\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{4-Y})^{\ell}(m_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{2})\Big)^{\frac{1}{\ell}}=\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{4-Y}\Big(m_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{2}\Big)^{\frac{1}{\ell}}\rightarrow 0.

Since Δn−1​vn4−Y≪Δnβ′​(4−Y)−1≪Δns\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{4-Y}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\beta^{\prime}(4-Y)-1}\ll\Delta_{n}^{s} for small enough s>0s>0, the above vanishes by picking ℓ\ell large enough. In light of (26), we also have ∑i=1n𝔼​(Yip|ℱi−1)(Δn​∑j=1Kmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ))p→0\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}^{p}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{(\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau))^{p}}\rightarrow 0 as n→∞n\rightarrow\infty for such an ℓ\ell. To show T2=oP​(1)T_{2}=o_{P}(1), recall mn=O​(Δn−12)m_{n}=O(\Delta_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2}}) and, thus, by Proposition 1 and (26),

∑i=1n𝔼​(Yi|ℱi−1)\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) =mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​Δn​σti−12+mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​C1,i​Δn​vn2−Y\displaystyle=\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\Delta_{n}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}+\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y}
+mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​D1,i​Δn2​vn−Y+OP​(mn​Δn2​vn−2−Y)+oP​(1).\displaystyle+\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)D_{1,i}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-Y}+O_{P}(\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(1). (31)

Hence,

T2\displaystyle T_{2} =∑i=1n𝔼​(Yi|ℱi−1)Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)−mn​Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)​σti−12−mn​A​(vn,mn)\displaystyle=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Y_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}-\sqrt{m_{n}}A(v_{n},m_{n})
=OP​(mn​Δn2​vn−2−Y),\displaystyle=O_{P}(\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-2-Y}),

which vanishes due to the condition mn≪Δn−4​vn4+2​Ym_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-4}v_{n}^{4+2Y}. To obtain T1→s​tZ1T_{1}\xrightarrow{st}Z_{1}, by Theorem 2.2.15 in [10], it suffices to check the condition:

∑i=1n𝔼i−1​(Yi​Δi​M)→0,\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(Y_{i}\Delta_{i}M\big)\rightarrow 0, (32)

where MM is either WW or BB or is in the set 𝒩\mathcal{N} containing all bounded martingales orthogonal to WW and BB. The proof of (32) is technical and is deferred to Appendix A.2. This concludes the proof for Z~n​(mn,vn)→s​tZ1\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\xrightarrow{st}Z_{1}.

d) To establish the joint convergence (20) and the asymptotic independence of T1,T2T_{1},T_{2}, it is sufficient to show that

supi|𝔼((ΔiX)2𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}ΔiB|ℱi−1)|=oP(Δn3/2),\displaystyle\sup_{i}\Big|\mathbb{E}\big((\Delta_{i}X)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)\Big|=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}), (33)

which is shown in Appendix A.2. Indeed, from (33) we obtain:

∑i=1n|𝔼(YiYi′|ℱi−1)|\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Big|\mathbb{E}(\left.Y_{i}Y^{\prime}_{i}\right|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})\Big|
=mn​Δnmn​Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)⋅|(−∑l=1i−1Kmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ))​𝟏τ≥ti+(∑l=inKmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ))​𝟏τ<ti|\displaystyle\quad=\frac{\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}}{\sqrt{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\cdot\left|\Big(-\sum_{l=1}^{i-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq t_{i}}+\Big(\sum_{l=i}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\mathbf{1}_{\tau<t_{i}}\right|
⋅|𝔼((ΔiX)2𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}ΔiB|ℱi−1)|\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\cdot\Big|\mathbb{E}\big((\Delta_{i}X)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)\Big|
=Δn2​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)⋅((∑l=1i−1Kmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ))​𝟏τ≥ti+(∑l=inKmn​Δn​(tl−1−τ))​𝟏τ<ti)​oP​(1)\displaystyle\quad=\Delta_{n}^{2}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\cdot\left(\Big(\sum_{l=1}^{i-1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq t_{i}}+\Big(\sum_{l=i}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{l-1}-\tau)\Big)\mathbf{1}_{\tau<t_{i}}\right)o_{P}(1)
=∫01Kmn​Δn​(v−τ)​(∫0vKmn​Δn​(s−τ)​𝑑s​𝟏τ≥v+∫v1Kmn​Δn​(s−τ)​𝑑s​𝟏τ<v)​𝑑v⋅oP​(1)→𝑃0.\displaystyle\quad=\int_{0}^{1}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(v-\tau)\Big({\int_{0}^{v}}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(s-\tau)ds\mathbf{1}_{\tau\geq v}+{\int_{v}^{1}}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(s-\tau)ds\mathbf{1}_{\tau<v}\Big)dv\cdot o_{P}(1)\xrightarrow{P}0.

In view of (27) and (32), one can finally apply Theorem 2.2.15 in [10] to conclude the proof. ♢\diamondsuit

The next result is the second key ingredient needed for our debiasing method. For an arbitrary fixed ζ>1\zeta>1, it establishes the convergence rate of the difference Z~n​(mn,ζ​vn)−Z~n​(mn,vn)\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})-\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}), i.e. of c^n,1​(mn,ζ​vn)−c^n,1​(mn,vn)\hat{c}_{n,1}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})-\hat{c}_{n,1}(m_{n},v_{n}) subject to a bias correction, which we exploit in our debiasing procedure.

Theorem 2.

Suppose that 1<Y<21<Y<2, log​(n)≪mn\sqrt{\mathrm{log}(n)}\ll m_{n}, mn=O​(Δn−12)m_{n}=O(\Delta_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2}}), Δnβ≪vn≪Δnβ′\Delta_{n}^{\beta}\ll v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\beta^{\prime}} with 14−Y<β′<β<12\frac{1}{4-Y}<\beta^{\prime}<\beta<\frac{1}{2}, and mn→∞m_{n}\rightarrow\infty such that vnγ​Δn−1≪mn≪Δn−5​vn8+Yv_{n}^{\gamma}\Delta_{n}^{-1}\ll m_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-5}v_{n}^{8+Y} with some γ<Y\gamma<Y. Then, under Assumptions 1 and 2, for an arbitrary fixed ζ>1\zeta>1, we have

un−1​(Z~n​(mn,ζ​vn)−Z~n​(mn,vn))→𝒟𝒩​(0,(C++C−)​|χτ|Y4−Y​(ζ4−Y−1)​∫K2​(x)​𝑑x),\displaystyle u_{n}^{-1}\big(\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})-\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\big)\xrightarrow{\mathcal{D}}\mathcal{N}\left(0,\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})|\chi_{\tau}|^{Y}}{4-Y}(\zeta^{4-Y}-1)\int K^{2}(x)dx\right), (34)

as n→∞n\rightarrow\infty, where un:=Δn−1/2​vn2−Y/2→0u_{n}:=\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}\rightarrow 0.

Remark 4.

The conditions on mnm_{n} in Theorem 2 are stricter than those in Theorem 1 due to the condition Δn−1​vnγ≪mn≪Δn−5​vn8+Y\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{\gamma}\ll m_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-5}v_{n}^{8+Y} (note Δn−5​vn8+Y≪Δn−4​vn4+2​Y\Delta_{n}^{-5}v_{n}^{8+Y}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-4}v_{n}^{4+2Y}, which was the the upper bound for mnm_{n} in Theorem 1). As we shall see, the optimal rate of convergence of the estimation error of our ultimate debiased estimator can be achieved by taking mn=θ​Δn−1/2m_{n}=\theta\Delta_{n}^{-1/2} for any constant θ>0\theta>0 (cf. Remark 2). In this bandwidth regime, the additional constraint on mnm_{n} in Theorem 2 reduces to Δn916+2​Y≪vn≪min⁡(Δn14−Y,Δn12​γ)\Delta_{n}^{\frac{9}{16+2Y}}\ll v_{n}\ll\min(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4-Y}},\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2\gamma}}), whose upper bound and lower bound can be made compatible only if Y<20/11{Y}<20/11.

Proof.

Denote

Zi=mn1/2Δn−1/2​vn2−Y/2​Kmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​(Δi​X)2​(𝟏{|Δi​X|≤ζ​vn}−𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}),Z_{i}=\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}\left(\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq\zeta v_{n}\}}-\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}\right),

and note that

un−1​(Z~n​(mn,ζ​vn)−Z~n​(mn,vn))\displaystyle u_{n}^{-1}\big(\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})-\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\big) =∑i=1nZiΔn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)−un−1​mn​(A​(ζ​vn,mn)−A​(vn,mn))\displaystyle=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}Z_{i}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-{u_{n}^{-1}\sqrt{m_{n}}\left(A(\zeta v_{n},m_{n})-A(v_{n},m_{n})\right)}
=:∑i=1nξiΔn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)\displaystyle=:\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\xi_{i}}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}
+(∑i=1n𝔼​(Zi|ℱi−1)Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)−un−1​mn​(A​(ζ​vn,mn)−A​(vn,mn))),\displaystyle\quad+\Big(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Z_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-u_{n}^{-1}\sqrt{m_{n}}\left(A(\zeta v_{n},m_{n})-A(v_{n},m_{n})\right)\Big),

where ξi:=Zi−𝔼​(Zi|ℱi−1)\xi_{i}:=Z_{i}-\mathbb{E}(Z_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}). The second term above is oP​(1)o_{P}(1). Indeed, since mn=O​(Δn−12)m_{n}=O(\Delta_{n}^{-\frac{1}{2}}), by (16) in Proposition 1,

∑i=1n𝔼​(Zi|ℱi−1)Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)−un−1​mn​(A​(ζ​vn,mn)−A​(vn,mn))\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}(Z_{i}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}-u_{n}^{-1}\sqrt{m_{n}}\big(A({\zeta v_{n}},m_{n})-A({v_{n}},m_{n})\big)
≲mn1/2​Δn2​vn−2−YΔn−1/2​vn2−Y/2+mn1/2​oP​(Δn−1/4​vn2−Y/2)Δn−1/2​vn2−Y/2\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-2-Y}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}+\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{-1/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2})}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}
=mn1/2​Δn5/2​vn−4−Y/2+oP​(1),\displaystyle\quad=m_{n}^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{5/2}v_{n}^{-4-Y/2}+o_{P}(1),

which vanishes given our assumption mn≪Δn−5​vn8+Ym_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-5}v_{n}^{8+Y}. Next we obtain the asymptotic behavior for ∑i=1nξi\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\xi_{i}} by verifying the conditions of Theorem 2.2.15 in [10]. Expression (14) in Proposition 1 yields

Var​(ξi|ℱi−1)\displaystyle\mathrm{Var}({\xi_{i}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}) =mnΔn−1​vn4−YKmn​Δn2(ti−1−τ)((ζ4−Y−1)C2,iΔnvn4−Y+oP(Δnvn4−Y)\displaystyle=\frac{m_{n}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{4-Y}}K^{2}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\Big((\zeta^{4-Y}-1){C_{2,i}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y}+{o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y})}
−{(ζ2−Y−1)C1,iΔnvn2−Y+(ζ−Y−1)D1,iΔn2vn−Y+OP(Δn3vn−2−Y)}2)\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\quad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad-\big\{(\zeta^{2-Y}-1){C_{1,i}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y}+(\zeta^{-Y}-1){D_{1,i}}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-Y}+{O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})}\big\}^{2}\Big)
=mnΔn−1​vn4−Y​Kmn​Δn2​(ti−1−τ)​((ζ4−Y−1)​C2,i​Δn​vn4−Y+oP​(Δn​vn4−Y)),\displaystyle=\frac{m_{n}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{4-Y}}K^{2}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big((\zeta^{4-Y}-1){C_{2,i}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y}+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y})\big),

where C2,i=(C++C−)​|χti−1|Y4−YC_{2,i}=\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})|\chi_{t_{i-1}}|^{Y}}{4-Y}. Therefore, with 1<Y<21<Y<2 and vn≪Δn1/(4−Y)v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/(4-Y)}, we obtain

s2​n2\displaystyle s_{2n}^{2} :=∑i=1nVar​(ξi|ℱi−1)\displaystyle:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathrm{Var}({\xi_{i}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})
=mn​Δn2​∑i=1nKmn​Δn2​(ti−1−τ)​(C++C−)​|χti−1|Y4−Y​(ζ4−Y−1)+oP​(1)\displaystyle=m_{n}\Delta_{n}^{2}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K^{2}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})|\chi_{t_{i-1}}|^{Y}}{4-Y}(\zeta^{{4-Y}}-1)+o_{P}(1)
⟶(C++C−)​|χτ|Y4−Y​(ζ4−Y−1)​∫K2​(x)​𝑑x.\displaystyle\longrightarrow\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})|\chi_{\tau}|^{Y}}{4-Y}(\zeta^{{4-Y}}-1)\int K^{2}(x)dx.

And consequently, with (26), we have

s2​n2(Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ))2→(C++C−)​|χτ|Y4−Y​(ζ4−Y−1)​∫K2​(x)​𝑑x.\frac{s_{2n}^{2}}{\big(\Delta_{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)\big)^{2}}\rightarrow\frac{(C_{+}+C_{-})|\chi_{\tau}|^{Y}}{4-Y}(\zeta^{{4-Y}}-1)\int K^{2}(x)dx. (35)

Similarly, for any p>2p>2, we have444By a standard localization argument, we may assume that σ\sigma is bounded.

∑i=1n𝔼​(ξip|ℱi−1)(Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ))p\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}({\xi_{i}^{p}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1})}{\big(\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)\big)^{p}}} ≲mnp/2Δn−p/2​vn2​p−p​Y/2​∑i=1nKmn​Δnp​(ti−1−τ)​(Δn​vn2​p−Y+Δnp)\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{m_{n}^{p/2}}{\Delta_{n}^{-p/2}v_{n}^{2p-pY/2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K^{p}_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}+\Delta_{n}^{p})
≲vn(p/2−1)​Ymnp/2−1​Δnp/2−1​∫Kp​(x)​𝑑x+Δnp/2mnp/2−1​vn2​p−p​Y/2​∫Kp​(x)​𝑑x.\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{v_{n}^{(p/2-1)Y}}{m_{n}^{p/2-1}\Delta_{n}^{p/2-1}}\int K^{p}(x)dx+\frac{\Delta_{n}^{p/2}}{m_{n}^{p/2-1}v_{n}^{2p-pY/2}}\int K^{p}(x)dx. (36)

In (36) the first term vanishes for any p>2p>2 since mn−1​Δn−1​vnY→0m_{n}^{-1}\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{Y}\rightarrow 0. For the second term, note that it can be written as (mn1/p​Δn​vn−2​Δn−1/2​mn−1/2​vnY/2)p\Big(m_{n}^{1/p}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-2}\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}m_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{Y/2}\Big)^{p}. By taking p↓2p\downarrow 2, the second term vanishes given Δn​vn−2≲Δn1−2​β→0\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-2}\lesssim\Delta_{n}^{1-2\beta}\rightarrow 0 with β<12\beta<\frac{1}{2} and mn−1​Δn−1​vnY→0m_{n}^{-1}\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{Y}\rightarrow 0.

In view of (36) and (35), what remains is to check the martingale technical condition from Theorem 2.2.15 in [10]. Specifically, due to (26), it requires us to show that as n→∞n\to\infty,

∑i=1n𝔼i−1​[ξi​Δn​M]=∑i=1n𝔼i−1​[Zi​Δn​M]​→𝑃​0,{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[\xi_{i}\Delta_{n}M\right]}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[Z_{i}\Delta_{n}M\right]\overset{P}{\to}0,

when M=WM=W or MM is a bounded martingale orthogonal to WW. Equivalently, it suffices to prove that

mn1/2Δn−1/2​vn2−Y/2​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​X)2​f​(Δi​X)​Δi​M]=oP​(1),\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}f(\Delta_{i}X)\Delta_{i}M\right]=o_{P}(1),

where f​(x):=𝟏{vn<|x|≤ζ​vn}f(x):=\mathbf{1}_{\{v_{n}<|x|\leq\zeta v_{n}\}}. Similar to the proof of Lemma 12 in [3], there exists a C2C^{2} smooth approximation fnf_{n} of ff such that for any η>0\eta>0,

𝟏{vn​(1+23​vnη)<|x|<ζ​vn​(1−23​vnη)}≤fn​(x)≤𝟏{vn​(1+13​vnη)<|x|<ζ​vn​(1−13​vnη)},\mathbf{1}_{\{v_{n}(1+\frac{2}{3}v_{n}^{\eta})<|x|<\zeta v_{n}(1-\frac{2}{3}v_{n}^{\eta})\}}\leq f_{n}(x)\leq\mathbf{1}_{\{v_{n}(1+\frac{1}{3}v_{n}^{\eta})<|x|<\zeta v_{n}(1-\frac{1}{3}v_{n}^{\eta})\}},
|fn′​(x)|≤Cvn1+η,|fn′′​(x)|≤Cvn2+2​η.|f^{\prime}_{n}(x)|\leq\frac{C}{v_{n}^{1+\eta}},\quad|f^{\prime\prime}_{n}(x)|\leq\frac{C}{v_{n}^{2+2\eta}}.

Then, the result follows from the following two limits

mn1/2Δn−1/2​vn2−Y/2​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​X)2​(f−fn)​(Δi​X)​Δi​M]→0,\displaystyle\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}(f-f_{n})(\Delta_{i}X)\Delta_{i}M\right]\to 0, (37)

and

mn1/2Δn−1/2​vn2−Y/2​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​X)2​fn​(Δi​X)​Δi​M]=oP​(1).\displaystyle\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}f_{n}(\Delta_{i}X)\Delta_{i}M\right]=o_{P}(1). (38)

While the proof of (37) is relatively straightforward, the proof of (38) is nontrivial and lengthy. This is shown in Appendix A.3.

♢\diamondsuit

Finally we are ready to formally construct our debiasing estimators. Our debiasing steps follow the same idea as in [12]. Write ζ→k=(ζ1,…,ζk)\vec{\zeta}_{k}=(\zeta_{1},\dots,\zeta_{k}), where ζ1,…,ζk>1\zeta_{1},\dots,\zeta_{k}>1 are fixed constants. Let

c~n(k)​(mn,vn,ζ→k)\displaystyle\widetilde{c}^{(k)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k}) :=c~n(k−1)​(mn,vn,ζ→k−1)\displaystyle:=\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})
−(c~n(k−1)​(mn,ζk​vn,ζ→k−1)−c~n(k−1)​(mn,vn,ζ→k−1))2c~n(k−1)​(mn,ζk2​vn,ζ→k−1)−2​c~n(k−1)​(mn,ζk​vn,ζ→k−1)+c~n(k−1)​(mn,vn,ζ→k−1),\displaystyle\quad-\frac{\big(\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})-\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})\big)^{2}}{\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}^{2}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})-2\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})+\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})}, (39)

for each k≥1k\geq 1, with c~n(0)​(mn,vn)=c^n​(mn,vn)\widetilde{c}^{(0)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})=\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}). Our next theorem is the second main result of this paper; it establishes a CLT for the feasible estimator c~n(2)​(mn,vn,ζ→2)\widetilde{c}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}).

Theorem 3.

Let

Z~n(2)​(mn,vn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) :=mn​(c~n(2)​(mn,vn,ζ→2)−c^n,2​(mn)).\displaystyle:=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\widetilde{c}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2})-\hat{c}_{n,2}(m_{n})\Big).

Then, under the assumptions and notation of Theorems 1 and 2, as n→∞n\rightarrow\infty,

(Z~n(2)​(mn,vn),Z~n′​(mn))→s​t(Z1,Z2).\displaystyle(\tilde{Z}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}),\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n}))\xrightarrow{st}\mathcal{(}Z_{1},{Z_{2}}). (40)

Furthermore, if we set

mn​Δn→θ,withθ∈[0,∞),m_{n}\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}\rightarrow\theta,\quad\text{with}\quad\theta\in{[0,\infty)},

we have the following stable convergence in law, as n→∞n\rightarrow\infty:

mn​(c~n(2)​(mn,vn,ζ→2)−στ2)→s​tZ1+θ​Z2.\sqrt{m_{n}}(\tilde{c}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2})-\sigma_{\tau}^{2})\xrightarrow{st}Z_{1}+\theta{Z_{2}}. (41)
Remark 5.

Recall that Remark 2 identifies two bandwidth regimes of primary importance: (i) 0<θ<∞0<\theta<\infty, and (ii) θ=0\theta=0, both with a convergence rate dictated by mn−1/2.m_{n}^{-1/2}. In case (i), a rate-optimal (feasible) CLT for c~n(2)​(mn,vn,ζ→2)\tilde{c}_{n}^{(2)}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}) is attained in (41) since mn−1/2≍Δn1/4m_{n}^{-1/2}\asymp\Delta_{n}^{1/4}, provided 1≤Y<20/111\leq Y<20/11, but no CLT is available in case (i) when Y≥20/11Y\geq 20/11. In case (ii), the rate is strictly slower than Δn1/4\Delta_{n}^{1/4} (see Remark 2 for details), but a CLT still holds for c~n(2)​(mn,vn,ζ→2)\tilde{c}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}) even when 20/11≤Y<220/11\leq Y<2 at the expense of a deteriorating rate. Indeed, since mn≪Δn−5​vn8+Ym_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-5}v_{n}^{8+Y} and vn≪Δn14−Yv_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4-Y}}, we have mn≪Δn(6​Y−12)/(4−Y)m_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{(6Y-12)/(4-Y)} and hence mn−1/2≫Δn(6−3​Y)/(4−Y)m_{n}^{-1/2}\gg\Delta_{n}^{(6-3Y)/(4-Y)}, which tends to zero more slowly as YY gets closer to 22.

Remark 6.

In Theorem 3, we proceeded with a two-step debiasing procedure to iteratively remove bias terms in A​(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}) one at a time. However, if the second-order term in (19) is negligible when multiplied by un−1​mnu_{n}^{-1}\sqrt{m_{n}} (and, thus, (34) is valid replacing A​(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}) with only the first-order term ∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​C1,i​Δn​vn2−Y\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y}), then only one debiasing step is needed. Specifically, for one-step debiasing it suffices that

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​C1,i​Δn2​vn−Y≪1.\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{-Y}\ll 1.

Therefore, we only require that un−1​mn​Δn​vn−Y≪1u_{n}^{-1}\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-Y}\ll 1 or, equivalently, mn≪Δn−3​vnY+4m_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-3}v_{n}^{Y+4}. In the optimal-rate bandwidth regime mn≍Δn−1/2m_{n}\asymp\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}, this imposes the relation Δn52​(Y+4)≪vn\Delta_{n}^{\frac{5}{2(Y+4)}}\ll v_{n}, but since vn≪Δn14−Yv_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4-Y}}, this yields the restriction Y<12/7Y<12/7. Similarly as in Remark 5, if Y≥12/7Y\geq 12/7 and θ=0\theta=0, the one-step debiased estimator c~n(1)​(mn,vn,ζ1)\tilde{c}^{(1)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{1}) will still enjoy a CLT centered at στ2\sigma_{\tau}^{2}, but with a rate strictly slower than Δn4−2​Y4−Y\Delta_{n}^{\frac{4-2Y}{4-Y}}, which tends to zero more slowly as YY gets closer to 22.

Proof.

Denote ℐ={(1,1),(2,1)}\mathcal{I}=\{(1,1),(2,1)\} and recall that

Z~n​(mn,vn)=mn​(c^n​(mn,vn)−Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12Δn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)−A​(vn,mn)),\displaystyle\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})=\sqrt{m_{n}}\left(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-\frac{\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}}{\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}}-{A(v_{n},m_{n})}\right), (42)

where

A(vn,mn)=∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​C1,i​Δn​vn2−YΔn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)+∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​D1,i​Δn2​vn−YΔn​∑j=1nKmn​Δn​(tj−1−τ)=:∑(i,j)∈ℐai,j(vn).\displaystyle A(v_{n},{m_{n}})=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau){C_{1,i}\Delta_{n}}v_{n}^{2-Y}}{\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}}+\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau){D_{1,i}}{\Delta_{n}^{2}}v_{n}^{-Y}}{{\Delta_{n}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{j-1}-\tau)}}}=:\sum_{(i,j)\in\mathcal{I}}a_{i,j}(v_{n}).

We introduce the following notation:

ηi,j​(ζ):=ζ2−2​(i−j)−j​Y−1,\displaystyle\eta_{i,j}(\zeta)=\zeta^{2-2(i-j)-jY}-1,
Ψn:=un−1​(Z~n​(ζ12​mn,vn)−2​Z~n​(ζ1​mn,vn)+Z~n​(mn,vn))=OP​(1),\displaystyle\Psi_{n}=u_{n}^{-1}\big(\tilde{Z}_{n}(\zeta_{1}^{2}m_{n},v_{n})-2\tilde{Z}_{n}(\zeta_{1}m_{n},v_{n})+\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\big)=O_{P}(1),
Φn:=un−1​(Z~n​(ζ​mn,vn)−Z~n​(mn,vn))=OP​(1),\displaystyle\Phi_{n}=u_{n}^{-1}\big(\tilde{Z}_{n}(\zeta m_{n},v_{n})-\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\big)=O_{P}(1),

where OP​(1)O_{P}(1) is a consequence of Theorem 2. Note that, for any (i,j)(i,j) we have

ai,j​(ζ​vn)−ai,j​(vn)=ηi,j​(ζ)​ai,j​(vn),\displaystyle a_{i,j}(\zeta v_{n})-a_{i,j}(v_{n})=\eta_{i,j}(\zeta)a_{i,j}(v_{n}), (43)
ai,j​(ζ2​vn)−2​ai,j​(ζ​vn)+ai,j​(vn)=ηi,j2​(ζ)​ai,j​(vn).\displaystyle a_{i,j}(\zeta^{2}v_{n})-2a_{i,j}(\zeta v_{n})+a_{i,j}(v_{n})=\eta_{i,j}^{2}(\zeta)a_{i,j}(v_{n}).

Recall Δn​vn−2≪1\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-2}\ll 1 gives the order comparison:

a1,1​(vn)≫a2,1​(vn).\displaystyle a_{1,1}(v_{n})\gg a_{2,1}(v_{n}). (44)

In the first stage of debiasing, the leading order term a1,1​(vn)a_{1,1}(v_{n}) is removed.

First step: removal of a1,1​(vn)a_{1,1}(v_{n})

Let

c~n(1)​(mn,vn,ζ1)\displaystyle\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{1}) =c^n​(mn,vn)−(c^n​(mn,ζ1​vn)−c^n​(mn,vn))2c^n​(mn,ζ12​vn)−2​c^n​(mn,ζ1​vn)+c^n​(mn,vn)\displaystyle=\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-\frac{\Big(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta_{1}v_{n})-\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\Big)^{2}}{{\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta_{1}^{2}v_{n})}-2\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta_{1}v_{n})+\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})}
=:c^n(mn,vn)−a^1,1(vn).\displaystyle=:\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-\hat{a}_{1,1}(v_{n}). (45)

Note that, due to (42)-(3),

c^n​(mn,ζ​vn)−c^n​(mn,vn)\displaystyle\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})-\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) =mn−1/2​(Z~n​(mn,ζ​vn)−Z~n​(mn,vn))+An​(ζ​vn,mn)−An​(vn,mn)\displaystyle=m_{n}^{-1/2}\left(\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})-\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})\right)+A_{n}(\zeta v_{n},m_{n})-A_{n}(v_{n},m_{n})
=mn−1/2​un​Φn+An​(ζ​vn,mn)−An​(vn,mn).\displaystyle=m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Phi_{n}+A_{n}(\zeta v_{n},m_{n})-A_{n}(v_{n},m_{n}).

Similarly, we can write:

c^n​(mn,ζ2​vn)−2​c^n​(mn,ζ​vn)+c^n​(mn,vn)\displaystyle\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta^{2}v_{n})-2\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\zeta v_{n})+\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) =mn−1/2​un​Ψn+An​(ζ2​vn,mn)−2​An​(ζ​vn,mn)+An​(vn,mn).\displaystyle=m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Psi_{n}+A_{n}(\zeta^{2}v_{n},m_{n})-2A_{n}(\zeta v_{n},m_{n})+A_{n}(v_{n},m_{n}).

Then, in the light of Proposition 1 and (43), we may expand a^1,1​(vn)\hat{a}_{1,1}(v_{n}) as follows:

a^1,1​(vn)\displaystyle\hat{a}_{1,1}(v_{n}) =(∑(r,s)∈ℐηr,s​ar,s​(vn)+mn−1/2​un​Φn)2∑(r,s)∈ℐηr,s2​ar,s​(vn)+mn−1/2​un​Ψn\displaystyle=\frac{\big(\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}\eta_{r,s}a_{r,s}(v_{n})+m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Phi_{n}\big)^{2}}{\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}\eta^{2}_{r,s}a_{r,s}(v_{n})+m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Psi_{n}} (46)
=a1,1​(vn)+OP​(mn−1/2​un)\displaystyle=a_{1,1}(v_{n})+O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n})
+η2,1​a2,1​(vn)​(2​η1,1−η2,1)​a1,1+η2,1​a2,1​(vn)η1,12​a1,1​(vn)+η2,12​a2,1​(vn)+mn−1/2​un​Ψn,\displaystyle\quad+\eta_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})\frac{(2\eta_{1,1}-\eta_{2,1})a_{1,1}+\eta_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})}{\eta^{2}_{1,1}a_{1,1}(v_{n})+\eta^{2}_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})+m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Psi_{n}},

where OP​(mn−1/2​un)O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}) includes the cross products between ∑(r,s)∈ℐηr,s​ar,s​(vn)\sum_{(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}}\eta_{r,s}a_{r,s}(v_{n}) and mn−1/2​un​Φn=oP​(1)m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Phi_{n}=o_{P}(1), along with (mn−1/2​un​Φn)2(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Phi_{n})^{2} and mn−1/2​un​Ψn​a1,1m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Psi_{n}a_{1,1}, all divided by ∑(r,s)∈ℐηr,s2​ar,s​(vn)+mn−1/2​un​Ψn\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}\eta^{2}_{r,s}a_{r,s}(v_{n})+m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Psi_{n}.

To simplify the last term in (46), note that for any variable N=op​(a1,12​(vn))N=o_{p}\big(a_{1,1}^{2}(v_{n})\big),

N∑(r,s)∈ℐar,s​(vn)+Op​(mn−1/2​un)−N∑(r,s)∈ℐar,s​(vn)\displaystyle\frac{N}{\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}a_{r,s}(v_{n})+O_{p}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n})}-\frac{N}{\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}a_{r,s}(v_{n})}
=−N∑(r,s)∈ℐar,s​(vn)⋅OP​(mn−1/2​un)(∑(r,s)∈ℐar,s​(vn)+OP​(mn−1/2​un))\displaystyle\quad=-\frac{N}{\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}a_{r,s}(v_{n})}\cdot\frac{O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n})}{\big(\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(r,s)\in\mathcal{I}\end{subarray}}a_{r,s}(v_{n})+O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n})\big)}
=−Na1,12​(vn)​(1+op​(1))⋅OP​(mn−1/2​un)\displaystyle\quad=\frac{-N}{a_{1,1}^{2}(v_{n})(1+o_{p}(1))}\cdot O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n})
=oP​(mn−1/2​un),\displaystyle\quad=o_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}), (47)

where above, for simplicity, we omitted the coefficients associated with ai,j​(vn)a_{i,j}(v_{n}). The above shows that we can drop the term mn−1/2​un​Ψnm_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}\Psi_{n} in the denominator and can write (46) as follows

a^1,1​(vn)\displaystyle\hat{a}_{1,1}(v_{n}) =a1,1​(vn)+OP​(mn−1/2​un)\displaystyle=a_{1,1}(v_{n})+O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n})
+η2,1​a2,1​(vn)​(2​η1,1−η2,1)​a1,1+η2,1​a2,1​(vn)η1,12​a1,1​(vn)+η2,12​a2,1​(vn)\displaystyle\quad+\eta_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})\frac{(2\eta_{1,1}-\eta_{2,1})a_{1,1}+\eta_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})}{\eta^{2}_{1,1}a_{1,1}(v_{n})+\eta^{2}_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})}
=a1,1​(vn)+η~2,1​a2,1+η˘2,1​a2,12​(vn)η1,12​a1,1​(vn)+η2,12​a2,1​(vn)+OP​(mn−1/2​un),\displaystyle=a_{1,1}(v_{n})+\tilde{\eta}_{2,1}a_{2,1}+\breve{\eta}_{2,1}\frac{a_{2,1}^{2}(v_{n})}{\eta^{2}_{1,1}a_{1,1}(v_{n})+\eta^{2}_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})}+O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}),

for some constants η~2,1\tilde{\eta}_{2,1} and η˘2,1\breve{\eta}_{2,1}. Note that the third term above is OP​(a2,12/a1,1)O_{P}(a_{2,1}^{2}/a_{1,1}) and, thus, this term is oP​(mn−1/2​un)o_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}) due to our assumption mn≪Δn−5​vn8+Ym_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-5}v_{n}^{8+Y}. We conclude that

a^1,1​(vn)=a1,1​(vn)+η~2,1​a2,1​(vn)+OP​(mn−1/2​un).\hat{a}_{1,1}(v_{n})=a_{1,1}(v_{n})+\tilde{\eta}_{2,1}a_{2,1}(v_{n})+O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}). (48)

We now show the first debiasing step eliminates a1,1​(vn)a_{1,1}(v_{n}). Indeed, denoting a~2,1​(vn):=(1−η~2,1)​a2,1​(vn)\tilde{a}_{2,1}(v_{n}):=(1-\tilde{\eta}_{2,1})a_{2,1}(v_{n}), in light of (42), (3), and (48) and recalling that A​(vn,mn)=a1,1+a1,2A(v_{n},m_{n})=a_{1,1}+a_{1,2}, we see that

Z~n(1)​(mn,vn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}^{(1)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) :=mn​(c~n(1)​(mn,vn,ζ1)−a~2,1​(vn)−Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12)\displaystyle:=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{1})-\tilde{a}_{2,1}(v_{n})-\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Big)
=mn​(c^n​(mn,vn)−a^1,1​(vn)−a~2,1​(vn)−Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12)\displaystyle=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})-\hat{a}_{1,1}(v_{n})-\tilde{a}_{2,1}(v_{n})-\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Big)
=Z~n​(mn,vn)+OP​(un).\displaystyle=\tilde{Z}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})+O_{P}(u_{n}).

Therefore, (20) implies that

(Z~n(1)​(mn,vn),Z~n′​(mn))→s​t(Z1,Z2).\displaystyle(\tilde{Z}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n}),\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n}))\xrightarrow{st}\mathcal{(}Z_{1},Z_{2}). (49)

Second step: removal of a2,1​(vn)a_{2,1}(v_{n})

Similar to (3), we can define

c~n(2)​(mn,vn,ζ2,ζ1)\displaystyle\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(2)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{2},\zeta_{1}) =c~n(1)​(mn,vn,ζ1)−(c~n(1)​(mn,ζ2​vn,ζ1)−c~n(1)​(mn,vn,ζ1))2c~n(1)​(mn,ζ22​vn,ζ1)−2​c~n(1)​(mn,ζ2​vn,ζ1)+c~n(1)​(mn,vn,ζ1)\displaystyle=\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{1})-\frac{\Big(\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},\zeta_{2}v_{n},\zeta_{1})-\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{1})\Big)^{2}}{\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},\zeta_{2}^{2}v_{n},\zeta_{1})-2\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},\zeta_{2}v_{n},\zeta_{1})+\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{1})}
=:c~n(1)(mn,ζ2vn,ζ1)−a^2,1(vn).\displaystyle=:\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},\zeta_{2}v_{n},\zeta_{1})-\hat{a}_{2,1}(v_{n}). (50)

Similar to (46), we may expand a^2,1​(vn)\hat{a}_{2,1}(v_{n}) as follows:

a^2,1​(vn)=a~2,1​(vn)+OP​(mn−1/2​un).\displaystyle\hat{a}_{2,1}(v_{n})={\tilde{a}_{2,1}(v_{n})}+O_{P}(m_{n}^{-1/2}u_{n}). (51)

Then we see that

Z~n(2)​(mn,vn)\displaystyle\tilde{Z}^{(2)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n}) :=mn​(c~n(2)​(mn,vn,ζ2,ζ1)−Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12)\displaystyle:=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(2)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{2},\zeta_{1})-\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Big)
=mn​(c~n(1)​(mn,vn,ζ2,ζ1)−a^2,1​(vn)−Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12)\displaystyle=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{2},\zeta_{1})-\hat{a}_{2,1}(v_{n})-\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Big)
=mn​(c~n(1)​(mn,vn,ζ2,ζ1)−a~2,1​(vn)−Δn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12)+OP​(un)\displaystyle=\sqrt{m_{n}}\Big(\widetilde{c}_{n}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\zeta_{2},\zeta_{1})-\tilde{a}_{2,1}(v_{n})-\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Big)+O_{P}(u_{n})
=Z~n(1)​(mn,vn)+OP​(un).\displaystyle=\tilde{Z}^{(1)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n})+O_{P}(u_{n}). (52)

Again, (49) now implies that

(Z~n(2)​(mn,vn),Z~n′​(mn))→s​t(Z1,Z2).\displaystyle(\tilde{Z}_{n}^{(2)}(m_{n},v_{n}),\tilde{Z}^{\prime}_{n}(m_{n}))\xrightarrow{st}\mathcal{(}Z_{1},Z_{2}). (53)

To conclude the last two statements of the theorem, we follow the same arguments as in Remark 2. ♢\diamondsuit

4 Simulation

In the numerical experiments below, we evaluate the performance of our debiased estimators under a Heston-type volatility model in two different settings. First, for comparison, we replicate the parameter setting and sampling scheme used in [15], which incorporates a symmetric stable jump component, although this configuration is arguably unrealistic for most financial applications (e.g., the overall annualized volatility is set to 1). Second, we consider a parameter setting that better reflects the empirical features of financial data. In this case, we also truncate the increments of the stable Lévy process, as is commonly done in applications, and investigate the impact of different choices of the threshold parameter vnv_{n}.

4.1 Simulation with Stable Jump Component

Following [15], we consider the following model:

Xt\displaystyle X_{t} =X0+∫0tbt​𝑑t+∫0tVs​𝑑Ws+Jt,\displaystyle=X_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}b_{t}dt+\int_{0}^{t}\sqrt{V_{s}}\,dW_{s}+J_{t}, (54)
Vt\displaystyle V_{t} =V0+∫0tκ​(θ−Vs)​𝑑s+ξ​∫0tVs​𝑑Bs,\displaystyle=V_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\kappa(\theta-V_{s})ds+\xi\int_{0}^{t}\sqrt{V_{s}}\,dB_{s},

where BB and B′B^{\prime} are correlated standard Brownian motions with correlation ρ\rho, JJ is a strictly symmetric stable Lévy process 555The rstable package in R was used to simulate the YY-stable portion of the jump component in all cases. with Blumenthal-Getoor index YY and scale parameter 11 (note [15] includes an additional finite-activity component which we omit for simplicity). In this section, we take the same parameter values as in [15]:

X0=1,V0=0,ρ=0,bt≡1,κ=0.03,θ=1,ξ=1.5.X_{0}=1,\quad V_{0}=0,\quad\rho=0,\quad b_{t}\equiv 1,\quad\kappa=0.03,\quad\theta=1,\quad\xi=1.5.

In this simulation, we compare the performance of our estimator c^​(mn,vn)\hat{c}(m_{n},v_{n}) defined in (3), c~(1)​(mn,vn,ζ→1)\tilde{c}^{(1)}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{1}) and c~n,τ(2)​(mn,vn,ζ→2)\tilde{c}^{(2)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}) defined in (3) to the estimators σ^τ,n2​(un,h)\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h) and σ~τ,n2​(λ,un,h)\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) introduced in [15], which are based on the empirical characteristic approach of [12]. Specifically, σ^τ,n2​(un,h)\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)666[15] defines σ^τ,n2​(un,h)=σ¯τ,n2​(un,h)−2​hun2​Δn​(sinh⁡(σ¯τ,n2​(un,h)))2\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)=\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)-\frac{2h}{u_{n}^{2}\Delta_{n}}(\sinh(\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)))^{2} for simulation. The difference lies in the reciprocal placement of hh and Δn\Delta_{n} in the bias correction term. We interpret the version in [15] as a likely typo and instead follow the formulation consistent with [12]. and σ~τ,n2​(λ,un,h)\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) are defined as

σ^τ,n2​(un,h)\displaystyle\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h) =σ¯τ,n2​(un,h)−2​Δnun2​h​(sinh⁡(σ¯τ,n2​(un,h)))2,\displaystyle=\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)-\frac{2\Delta_{n}}{u_{n}^{2}h}(\sinh(\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)))^{2},
σ~τ,n2​(λ,un,h)\displaystyle\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) =σ^τ,n2​(un,h)−B~τ,n​(λ,un,h),\displaystyle=\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)-\tilde{B}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h),

where

σ¯τ,n2​(un,h)\displaystyle\bar{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h) =−2un2​log​(Sτ,n​(un,h)∨Δnh),\displaystyle=\frac{-2}{u_{n}^{2}}\mathrm{log}\left(S_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h)\vee\sqrt{\frac{\Delta_{n}}{h}}\right),
Sτ,n​(un,h)\displaystyle S_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h) =Δn​∑i=1nKh​(i​Δn−τ)​cos⁡(un​Δi​XΔn),\displaystyle=\Delta_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{h}(i\Delta_{n}-\tau)\cos\left(\frac{u_{n}\Delta_{i}X}{\sqrt{\Delta_{n}}}\right),

and B~τ,n​(λ,un,h)\tilde{B}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) is a bias-correction term777The formula of B~τ,n​(λ,un,h)\tilde{B}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) in [15] forces each summand in the denominator to be nonpositive. However, in our experiments, we found that omitting control of the sign of these terms significantly improved the performance of the estimators.
