B~τ,n​(λ,un,h)\displaystyle\tilde{B}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) =∑i=1⌊1mn​Δn⌋[σ^(i−1)​mn​Δn,n2​(λ​p​un,h)−σ^(i−1)​mn​Δn,n2​(p​un,h)]⋅[(σ^τ,n2​(λ​un,h)−σ^τ,n2​(un,h))∧0]∑i=1⌊1mn​Δn⌋(σ^(i−1)​mn​Δn,n2(λ2pun,h)−2σ^(i−1)​mn​Δn,n2((λpun,h)+σ^(i−1)​mn​Δn,n2(pun,h)),\displaystyle=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\rfloor}\left[{\hat{\sigma}}^{2}_{(i-1)m_{n}\Delta_{n},n}(\lambda pu_{n},h)-{\hat{\sigma}}^{2}_{(i-1)m_{n}\Delta_{n},n}(pu_{n},h)\right]\cdot{\left[(\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(\lambda u_{n},h)-\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h))\wedge 0\right]}}{\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\rfloor}\big({\hat{\sigma}}^{2}_{(i-1)m_{n}\Delta_{n},n}(\lambda^{2}pu_{n},h)-2{\hat{\sigma}}^{2}_{(i-1)m_{n}\Delta_{n},n}((\lambda pu_{n},h)+{\hat{\sigma}}^{2}_{(i-1)m_{n}\Delta_{n},n}(pu_{n},h)\big)},

which aggregates spot estimators across tt for improved finite-sample performance. This approach was also used in [12].

For comparison, for our one- and two-step debiased estimators c~m,τ(1)​(mn,vn,ζ→1)\tilde{c}^{(1)}_{m,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{1}) and c~n,τ(2)​(mn,vn,ζ→2)\tilde{c}^{(2)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}), we also adopt the debiasing adjustments of [15] and [12] described above. Specifically, denoting c~n,τ(k)​(mn,vn,ζ→k)\tilde{c}^{(k)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k}) the estimator c~n(k)​(mn,vn,ζ→k)\tilde{c}^{(k)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k}) at time τ\tau, we consider

c~n,τ(k)​(mn,vn,ζ→k)\displaystyle\widetilde{c}^{(k)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k}) :=c~n,τ(k−1)​(mn,vn,ζ→k−1)\displaystyle:=\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})
−(An(k)​(mn,vn,ζ→k)∨0)​(c~n,τ(k−1)​(mn,ζk​vn,ζ→k−1)−c~n,τ(k−1)​(mn,vn,ζ→k−1))∨0,\displaystyle\quad-\big(A^{(k)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k})\vee 0\big)\big(\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})-\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})\big)\vee 0,

where An(k):=An(k)​(mn,vn,ζ→k)A^{(k)}_{{n}}:=A^{(k)}_{n}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k}) is given by

An(k)=±∑i=1⌊1mn​Δn⌋(c~n,i​mn​Δn(k−1)​(mn,ζk​pk​vn,ζ→k−1)−c~n,i​mn​Δn(k−1)​(mn,pk​vn,ζ→k−1))∑i=1⌊1mn​Δn⌋(c~n,i​mn​Δn(k−1)​(mn,ζk2​pk​vn,ζ→k−1)−2​c~n,i​mn​Δn(k−1)​(mn,ζk​pk​vn,ζ→k−1)+c~n,i​mn​Δn(k−1)​(mn,pk​vn,ζ→k−1)),A_{n}^{(k)}=\pm\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\rfloor}\big(\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,im_{n}\Delta_{n}}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}p_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})-\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,im_{n}\Delta_{n}}(m_{n},p_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})\big)}{\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\rfloor}\big(\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,im_{n}\Delta_{n}}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}^{2}p_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})-2\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,im_{n}\Delta_{n}}(m_{n},\zeta_{k}p_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})+\widetilde{c}^{(k-1)}_{n,im_{n}\Delta_{n}}(m_{n},p_{k}v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{k-1})\big)},

where the sign of the bias terms are chosen as in [3] and cn,τ(0)​(mn,vn,ζ→0)=c^​(mn,vn)c^{(0)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{0})=\hat{c}(m_{n},v_{n}) at τ\tau, i.e., An(1)A_{n}^{(1)} is positive and An(2)A_{n}^{(2)} is negative, so as to ensure compatibility with the theoretical sign of the terms in A​(vn,mn)A(v_{n},m_{n}).

To evaluate estimation performance, we simulate MM independent paths and aggregate various pathwise error measures computed along each simulated path for each of the estimators considered above. Denoting the true value of the spot variance at tit_{i} in the jj-th path as σti,j2:=Vti,j\sigma^{2}_{t_{i},j}:=V_{t_{i},j} and a given estimator as σ^ti,j2\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{t_{i},j}, we consider an estimate of the pathwise root mean squared error (RMSE) on the time grid {li=i​⌊n/100⌋}i=10,…,90\{l_{i}=i\lfloor n/100\rfloor\}_{i=10,\dots,90} as follows:

R​M​S​E^:=1M​∑j=1MM​S​Ej,\widehat{RMSE}:=\sqrt{\frac{1}{M}\sum_{{j=1}}^{M}MSE_{j}}\,,

where M​S​Ej:=181​∑i=1090(σ^li,j2−σli,j2)2MSE_{j}:=\frac{1}{81}\sum_{i=10}^{90}(\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{l_{i},j}-\sigma^{2}_{l_{i},j})^{2}. Similarly, we also consider the mean absolute relative error A​R​E^\widehat{ARE} and the mean relative error R​E^\widehat{RE}:

A​R​E^:=1M​∑j=1MA​Ej​ and ​R​E^:=1M​∑j=1MEj,\widehat{ARE}:=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{j=1}^{M}AE_{j}\;\text{ and }\;\widehat{RE}:=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{j=1}^{M}E_{j},

where A​Ej:=181​∑i=1090|σ^li,j2−σli,j2|/σli,j2AE_{j}:=\frac{1}{81}\sum_{i=10}^{90}|\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{l_{i},j}-\sigma^{2}_{l_{i},j}|/\sigma^{2}_{l_{i},j} and Ej:=181​∑i=1090(σ^li,j2−σli,j2)/σli,j2E_{j}:=\frac{1}{81}\sum_{i=10}^{90}(\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{l_{i},j}-\sigma^{2}_{l_{i},j})/\sigma^{2}_{l_{i},j}.

For our estimators c^n​(mn,Δn)\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\Delta_{n}), c~m,τ(1)​(mn,vn,ζ→1)\tilde{c}^{(1)}_{m,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{1}) and c~n,τ(2)​(mn,vn,ζ→2)\tilde{c}^{(2)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}), we use the exponential kernel K​(x)=exp⁡(−|x|)/2K(x)=\exp({-|x|})/2 as well as the two-sided uniform kernel G​(x)=𝟏−1≤|x|≤1/2G(x)=\mathbf{1}_{-1\leq|x|\leq 1}/2, and set mn=Δn−1/2m_{n}=\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}, vn=B​V​Δn5/12v_{n}=\sqrt{BV}\Delta_{n}^{5/12}, where B​V=π2​∑i=2n|Δi​X|​|Δi−1​X|/TBV=\frac{\pi}{2}\sum_{i=2}^{n}|\Delta_{i}X||\Delta_{i-1}X|/T is the bipower estimator for the integrated volatility. For the estimators σ^τ,n2​(un,h)\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(u_{n},h) and σ~τ,n2​(λ,un,h)\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{\tau,n}(\lambda,u_{n},h) of [15], we take the kernel K3​(x)=1516​(1−x2)2​𝟏|x|≤1K_{3}(x)=\frac{15}{16}(1-x^{2})^{2}\mathbf{1}_{|x|\leq 1} as specified on [15, p. 1964]888K3K_{3} is the best-performing kernel among those considered in [15] that satisfies the assumptions of their results (in particular, that is continuously differentiable as assumed by their main theorem). We also use the best-performing bandwidth as reported in their simulations, h=Δn0.51h=\Delta_{n}^{0.51} and un=Δn0.0025B​Vu_{n}=\frac{\Delta_{n}^{0.0025}}{\sqrt{BV}}999Instead of using bipower variation for unu_{n}, the authors of [15] employed a scaled local bipower variation defined as B​Vτ=π2​(i2−i1)​Δn​∑i=i1i2|Δi​X|​|Δi+1​X|,BV_{\tau}=\frac{\pi}{2(i_{2}-i_{1})\Delta_{n}}\sum_{i=i_{1}}^{i_{2}}|\Delta_{i}X||\Delta_{i+1}X|, where i1=⌊τ−hΔn+1⌋∨1i_{1}=\left\lfloor\frac{\tau-h}{\Delta_{n}}+1\right\rfloor\vee 1 and i2=⌊τ+hΔn+1⌋∧ni_{2}=\left\lfloor\frac{\tau+h}{\Delta_{n}}+1\right\rfloor\wedge n. However, in our experiments, this choice lead to large RMSE when aggregating errors across various τ\tau, particularly for Y=1.2Y=1.2. In contrast, the estimators demonstrated greater stability with our proposed choice of unu_{n}.. The remaining tuning parameters ζ→1\vec{\zeta}_{1}, ζ→2\vec{\zeta}_{2}, λ\lambda, pp, p1p_{1}, (p1,p2)(p_{1},p_{2}) are selected via a grid search that minimizes R​M​S​E^\widehat{RMSE}101010Specifically, to each point in the grid, we simulated M=100M=100 independent paths to estimate the R​M​S​E^\widehat{RMSE} for the associated parameter settings.. The grid for ζ\zeta and λ\lambda ranged from 1.1 to 1.9 with increments of 0.05, while the grid for pp spanned from 0.1 to 0.9 with increments of 0.05. For reproducibility, where applicable, we also report the auxiliary tuning parameter values found in our grid search for each considered estimator.

As in [15], we take T=1T=1 month and n=8580n=8580, roughly corresponding to a 5-minute sampling frequency (assuming 24 hours of trading). For additional comparison, we also include the results for n=42900n=42900, corresponding to roughly 1-minute frequency data in this setup. Using M=1000M=1000 iterations, we report the results in Tables 1 and 2. We consider the values Y∈{0.8,1.2,1.6,1.75}Y\in\{0.8,1.2,1.6,1.75\}, which correspond to the cases where, in principle, no debiasing is needed (Y∈{0.8,1.2}Y\in\{0.8,1.2\}), one step of debiasing is needed (Y=1.6Y=1.6), and two steps are needed (Y=1.75)(Y=1.75) to attain asymptotic efficiency according to our theory, though we may observe very different finite sample behavior.

As shown in Tables 1 and 2, the two-step debiasing estimator c~n(2)\tilde{c}_{n}^{(2)} consistently delivers the best performance, with the lowest RMSE and ARE, and generally well-controlled error. The advantage of two-step debiasing becomes especially pronounced as YY increases: While the performance of σ^n2\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{n} and σ~n2\widetilde{\sigma}^{2}_{n} deteriorates sharply, the one- and two-step debiased estimators exhibit markedly greater robustness against increased jump activity. Notably, two-step debiasing yields improvement even where it is not strictly needed for asymptotically efficient estimation (Y=0.8,1.2Y=0.8,1.2). The pattern is similar at both 5-minute and 1-minute frequencies, where the two-step debiasing method is the only one that remains stable across all considered settings, offering reductions in RMSE often by a factor of 2 to 5 relative to the considered benchmarks.

Across kernel choices for c~n(i)\tilde{c}_{n}^{(i)}, the exponential kernel systematically outperforms the uniform kernel across all values of YY and at both 1- and 5-minute sampling frequencies. This finding is consistent with the established theoretical optimality of exponential kernels in related settings where debiasing is not required [8], and more broadly underscores the advantages of using unbounded kernels in spot volatility estimation. Overall, the two-step estimator with the exponential kernel achieves the strongest and most reliable performance among all configurations considered.

4.2 Simulation with truncated stable jump component

In this section, we consider a parameter setting that more closely reflects the empirical features of financial data. We also take a truncated stable Lévy process as the jump component, which is common in applications. We also study the effect of the truncation level vnv_{n}.

For this experiment, we fix a time unit of 1 year (i.e., tt is measured in years). The increments of the observed process (corresponding to an asset’s log return over (ti−1,ti](t_{i-1},t_{i}]) are given by

Δi​X\displaystyle\Delta_{i}X =Xti−Xti−1=∫ti−1tiVs​𝑑Ws+(Δi​J∧0.005),\displaystyle=X_{t_{i}}-X_{t_{i-1}}=\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\sqrt{V_{s}}\,dW_{s}+(\Delta_{i}J\wedge 0.005),\, (55)

where JJ is a symmetric YY-stable Lévy process with scale parameter 0.50.5 and VV follows the same Heston model (54) with parameter values as in [3]:

ρ=−0.5,κ=5,ξ=0.5,θ=0.16.\rho=-0.5,\quad\kappa=5,\quad\xi=0.5,\quad\theta=0.16.

In particular, we note the annualized average volatility is .16=.4\sqrt{.16}=.4, which is more realistic for financial data. Assuming 252 trading days per year, and a 6.5 hour trading day, we set Δn=(252∗6.5∗12)−1\Delta_{n}=(252*6.5*12)^{-1}, corresponding to a sampling frequency of 5 minutes. We consider a time horizon of 3 months (T=14T=\frac{1}{4}), yielding a sample size of n=T/Δn=4914n=T/\Delta_{n}=4914. In our experiments, we examine performance in the cases Y=1.6Y=1.6 and Y=1.75Y=1.75, corresponding to 1 and 2 steps of debiasing required for efficiency, and use an exponential kernel for our estimators c^n​(mn,Δn)\hat{c}_{n}(m_{n},\Delta_{n}), c~m,τ(1)​(mn,vn,ζ→1)\tilde{c}^{(1)}_{m,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{1}) and c~n,τ(2)​(mn,vn,ζ→2)\tilde{c}^{(2)}_{n,\tau}(m_{n},v_{n},\vec{\zeta}_{2}). The tuning parameters are similar to the previous section, with ζ→1\vec{\zeta}_{1}, ζ→2\vec{\zeta}_{2}, λ\lambda, pp, p1p_{1}, and (p1,p2)(p_{1},p_{2}) being selected via a grid search that minimizes R​M​S​E^\widehat{RMSE} over 100 iterations (using the same grid as described in previous section), but here we take vn=B​V​v0v_{n}=\sqrt{BV}v_{0}, for different v0v_{0} to assess the sensitivity of our methods to the threshold choice. We report the performance for our estimators across various threshold choices v0v_{0} in Table 3 (Y=1.6)(Y=1.6) and in Table 4 (Y=1.75)(Y=1.75) as measured by R​M​S​E^\widehat{RMSE}, A​R​E^\widehat{ARE} and R​E^\widehat{RE} using M=1000M=1000 paths. In each table, we also include the performance of the estimators of [15] for comparison. We also report the auxiliary tuning parameter values found in our grid search.

As shown in Tables 3 and 4, for both Y=1.6Y=1.6 and Y=1.75Y=1.75 the two-step estimator c~n(2)\tilde{c}_{n}^{(2)} again provides the most reliable performance, delivering the lowest or near-lowest RMSE and ARE across all v0v_{0} considered. The advantage of debiasing is most pronounced at the moderate threshold choices v0=Δn20/48=Δn5/12v_{0}=\Delta_{n}^{20/48}=\Delta_{n}^{5/12} and v0=Δn21/48v_{0}=\Delta_{n}^{21/48}, where the two-step estimators offer reductions in RMSE over σ^n2\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{n} and σ~n2\tilde{\sigma}^{2}_{n} by roughly a factor of 2, and these improvements are observed consistently for both Y=1.6Y=1.6 and Y=1.75Y=1.75. Remarkably, the choice v0=Δn5/12v_{0}=\Delta_{n}^{5/12} is the same as suggested by the theory for two-step debiasing in the integrated volatility case (see [3]). Broadly, these findings highlight the benefit of two-step debiasing beyond specific threshold choices, offering reliable nontrivial reductions in MSE across a variety of jump activity levels.

Appendix A Additional technical proofs

Throughout the proofs below, we make use of the following notation:

xi:=\displaystyle x_{i}:= bti−1​Δn+σti−1​Δi​W+χti−1​Δi​J,x^i:=σti−1​Δi​W+χti−1​Δi​J,\displaystyle b_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{n}+\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J,\;\;\hat{x}_{i}:=\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J,
εi:=\displaystyle\varepsilon_{i}:= Δi​X−xi=∫ti−1tiσt​𝑑Wt−σti−1​Δi​W+∫ti−1tiχt​𝑑Jt−χti−1​Δi​J+∫ti−1tibt​𝑑t−bti−1​Δn.\displaystyle\Delta_{i}X-x_{i}=\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\sigma_{t}dW_{t}-\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\chi_{t}dJ_{t}-\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J+\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}b_{t}dt-b_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{n}. (56)

In what follows we often refer to the following standard moment estimates of the error terms (see Lemma 3 in [4]):

𝔼​[|εi|p|ℱti−1]≤C​Δn(2∧p)+p2,\mathbb{E}\left[|\varepsilon_{i}|^{p}\big|\mathcal{F}_{t_{i-1}}\right]\leq C\Delta_{n}^{\frac{(2\wedge p)+p}{2}}, (57)

for any p>0p>0 and a constant CC.

A.1 Proof of Proposition 1

Similar to [3] and [4], we approximate the original process XtX_{t} by

Xt′:=∫0tbs​𝑑s+∫0tσs​𝑑Ws+∫0tχs​𝑑Js∞,X_{t}^{\prime}:=\int_{0}^{t}b_{s}\,ds+\int_{0}^{t}\sigma_{s}\,dW_{s}+\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s}\,dJ_{s}^{\infty}, (58)

where, with δ0∈(0,1)\delta_{0}\in(0,1) being chosen such that q​(x)>0q(x)>0 for all |x|≤δ0|x|\leq\delta_{0} and denoting the jump measure of JJ and its compensated version as NN and N¯\bar{N}, respectively, the process J∞J^{\infty} is defined as

Jt∞:=(b¯+∫δ0<|x|≤1x​ν​(d​x))​t+∫0t∫|x|≤δ0x​N¯​(d​s,d​x)+J˘t.J_{t}^{\infty}:=\left(\bar{b}+\int_{\delta_{0}<|x|\leq 1}x\,\nu(dx)\right)t+\int_{0}^{t}\int_{|x|\leq\delta_{0}}x\,\bar{N}(ds,dx)+\breve{J}_{t}. (59)

The term J˘t\breve{J}_{t} is a pure-jump Lévy process, independent of JJ, with characteristic triplet (0,0,ν˘)(0,0,\breve{\nu}), where its Lévy measure, ν˘\breve{\nu}, is given by

ν˘​(d​x):=e−|x|p​(C+​𝟏(0,∞)​(x)+C−​𝟏(−∞,0)​(x))​𝟏|x|>δ0​|x|−1−Y​d​x,\breve{\nu}(dx):=e^{-|x|^{p}}\left(C_{+}\mathbf{1}_{(0,\infty)}(x)+C_{-}\mathbf{1}_{(-\infty,0)}(x)\right)\mathbf{1}_{|x|>\delta_{0}}|x|^{-1-Y}\,dx,

for a fixed constant p<1∧Yp<1\wedge Y. Additionally, we write

Jt0:=Jt−Jt∞=∫0t∫|x|>δ0x​N​(d​s,d​x)−J˘t,J_{t}^{0}:=J_{t}-J_{t}^{\infty}=\int_{0}^{t}\int_{|x|>\delta_{0}}xN(ds,dx)-\breve{J}_{t}, (60)

and note that

Xt−Xt′=∫0t∫δ​(s,z)​𝔭​(d​s,d​z)+∫0tχs​𝑑Js0.X_{t}-X_{t}^{\prime}=\int_{0}^{t}\int\delta(s,z)\mathfrak{p}(ds,dz)+\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s}dJ_{s}^{0}.

In conclusion, the process X′X^{\prime} contains the continuous part and the jumps of the infinite variation, and X−X′X-X^{\prime} only includes the jumps of bounded variation.

A.1.1 Proof of (14)

This expansion follows from the one obtained in [3, Lemma 4]. Indeed, the condition Y<8/5Y<8/5 stated in the hypotheses of that lemma is not used in its proof.

A.1.2 Proof of (15)

The proof of (15) follows along the lines of the proof of Lemma 2 and Lemma 5 in [3]. The main difference is that [3] has the constraint vn≫Δn32​(2+Y)v_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{2(2+Y)}} as well as the condition Y≤8/5Y\leq 8/5. However, these restrictions were imposed to achieve an error term of order oP​(Δn3/2)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}) in the expansion therein, while, in our case, it suffices to have an error of order oP​(Δn54)+OP​(Δn3​vn−2−Y)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{5}{4}})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y}). Under this more relaxed constraint, we will show the statement (15) holds under the entire range Y∈(0,1)∪(1,2)Y\in(0,1)\cup(1,2).

Note that the proof of Lemma 2 in [3] remains valid for 0<Y<10<Y<1, without relying on the condition vn≫Δn32​(2+Y)v_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{2(2+Y)}}. Hence, Lemma 2 holds for 0<Y<10<Y<1 under the weaker condition Δn1/2≪vn≪Δn1/(4−Y)\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\ll v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/(4-Y)}, which in turn implies (15). In the following, we focus on the proof for the case 1<Y<21<Y<2.

First, we show that the expansion (15) holds when XX is a sum of a Brownian motion and the tempered stable Lévy process J∞J^{\infty} defined in (59). This fact actually follows directly from Proposition 2 in [4]. Indeed, it was shown there that for such a process the error, excluding exponentially decaying terms, is of order OP​(Δn3​vn−Y−2)+OP​(Δn2​vn2−2​Y)+OP​(Δn​vn2−δ¯)+OP​(Δn3/2​vn1−Y/2)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-Y-2})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2-2Y})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-\bar{\delta}})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}v_{n}^{1-Y/2}). However, we observe that both Δn​vn2−δ¯\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-\bar{\delta}} and Δn32​vn1−Y/2\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{2}}v_{n}^{1-Y/2} are oP​(Δn54)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{5}{4}}) and Δn3​vn−Y−2≫Δn2​vn2−2​Y\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-Y-2}\gg\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2-2Y} since vn≪Δn1/(4−Y)v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/(4-Y)}. Therefore, the expansion of Proposition 2 in [4] is valid for any Y∈(1,2)Y\in(1,2) with the errors being of order OP​(Δn3​vn−2−Y)+oP​(Δn5/4)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}).

As in [3], we next extend the expansion for the process X′X^{\prime} defined in (58), which broadly replaces JJ with J∞J^{\infty} and omits the last bounded variation Poisson term in XX. This is done in Lemma 2 in [3]. To conclude that the expansion therein holds, but with an adjusted error of order OP​(Δn3​vn−2−Y)+oP​(Δn5/4)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}), it suffices to show the terms Ri,1R_{i,1} and Ri,4R_{i,4} appearing in the proof of [3, Lemma 2] are of order oP​(Δn5/4)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}). We only show Ri,4=oP​(Δn5/4)R_{i,4}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}) since the argument for Ri,1R_{i,1} is similar. It suffices to bound Di,1D_{i,1} and Di,2D_{i,2} as defined on [3, p.20]. To obtain Di,1=oP​(Δn5/4)D_{i,1}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}), under the constraint 1<Y<21<Y<2, the analog of [3, eq. (B.12)] reads

Δn​vn1−Y​δ≪Δn5/4⇔δ≪Δn1/4​vnY−1.\displaystyle\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{1-Y}\delta\ll\Delta_{n}^{5/4}\quad\iff\quad\delta\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/4}v_{n}^{Y-1}. (61)

To obtain Di,2=oP​(Δn5/4)D_{i,2}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}) for 1<Y<21<Y<2, it suffices to bound the terms 𝒱i,2\mathcal{V}_{i,2} and 𝒱i,3\mathcal{V}_{i,3} defined on [3, p. 21]. Following the same argument leading to [3, eq. (B.13)], to obtain 𝒱i,1=oP​(Δn5/4),\mathcal{V}_{i,1}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}), we require, for arbitrarily small s′,s′′>0s^{\prime},s^{\prime\prime}>0,

Δn5/2−s′​vn1−Y−s′′​δ−1≪Δn5/4⇔δ≫Δn5/4−s′​vn1−Y−s′′.\displaystyle\Delta_{n}^{5/2-s^{\prime}}v_{n}^{1-Y-s^{\prime\prime}}\delta^{-1}\ll\Delta_{n}^{5/4}\quad\iff\quad\delta\gg\Delta_{n}^{5/4-s^{\prime}}v_{n}^{1-Y-s^{\prime\prime}}. (62)

The conditions (61) and (62) are consistent for any 1<Y<21<Y<2, since

Δn5/4−s′​vn1−Y−s′′≪Δn1/4​vnY−1⇔Δn1−s′2​Y−2+s′′≪vn,\Delta_{n}^{5/4-s^{\prime}}v_{n}^{1-Y-s^{\prime\prime}}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/4}v_{n}^{Y-1}\Leftrightarrow\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1-s^{\prime}}{2Y-2+s^{\prime\prime}}}\ll v_{n},

which holds for sufficiently small s′,s′′s^{\prime},s^{\prime\prime} under our condition Δn12−s≪vn\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}-s}\ll v_{n}. Finally, for the term 𝒱i,3,\mathcal{V}_{i,3}, since vn≪Δn14−Yv_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{4-Y}}, the condition δ≫Δn12​vnY2\delta\gg\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}}v_{n}^{\frac{Y}{2}} imposed at the end of the proof of [3, Lemma 2] is consistent with (61). The condition δ≫Δn12​vnY2\delta\gg\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}}v_{n}^{\frac{Y}{2}} enables us to apply [4, Lemma 4] and conclude that 𝔼​(Vi,3)=O​(Δn2​vn2−2​Y)\mathbb{E}(V_{i,3})=O(\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2-2Y}), which is obviously also O​(Δn3​vn−Y−2)O(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-Y-2}), as desired.

To conclude the proof, with the updated error OP​(Δn3​vn−2−Y)+oP​(Δn5/4)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}) and the more general process XX, it remains to establish an analog of Lemma 5 in [3], which allows us to add the last bounded variation term to XX and go from J∞J^{\infty} to the more general tempered stable Lévy process JJ. This is detailed in Section A.1.4 below.

A.1.3 Proof of (16)

We first note that the expansion (16) holds when XX is a sum of a Brownian motion and the independent tempered stable Lévy process J∞J^{\infty} on account of [4, Proposition 2], which implies that that the error terms in (16) are OP​(Δn3​vn−Y−2)+OP​(Δn2​vn2−2​Y)+OP​(Δn​vn2−δ¯)+OP​(Δn3/2​vn1−Y/2)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-Y-2})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2-2Y})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-\bar{\delta}})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}v_{n}^{1-Y/2}). As with the proof of (15), we can similarly check that OP​(Δn3​vn−2−Y)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y}) and oP​(Δn34​vn4−Y2)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}) dominate the higher order terms Δn2​vn2−2​Y\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2-2Y}, Δn32​vn1−Y2\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{2}}v_{n}^{1-\frac{Y}{2}} and Δn​vn2−δ¯\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-\bar{\delta}} therein.

Next, similarly to [3, Lemma 3], we argue that the expansion (16) holds for the process X′X^{\prime} defined in (58). Indeed, following the proof of [3, Lemma 3], it suffices to obtain bounds for the terms 𝒟¯i,1\overline{\mathcal{D}}_{i,1} and 𝒟¯i,2\overline{\mathcal{D}}_{i,2} on [3, p.22]. First to show 𝒟¯i,1=oP​(Δn34​vn4−Y2)\overline{\mathcal{D}}_{i,1}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}), we arrive at the constraint analogous to [3, eq. (B.17)]:

Δn​vn1−Y​δ≪Δn34​vn4−Y2⇔δ≪Δn−14​vn1+Y2.\displaystyle\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{1-Y}\delta\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}\quad\iff\quad\delta\ll\Delta_{n}^{-\frac{1}{4}}v_{n}^{1+\frac{Y}{2}}. (63)

Similarly, to obtain 𝒟¯i,2=oP​(Δn34​vn4−Y2)+OP​(Δn3​vn−Y−2)\overline{\mathcal{D}}_{i,2}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-Y-2}), we first recall that (see [3, eq. (B.19)]), under the constraint δ≫Δn1/2​vnY/2\delta\gg\Delta_{n}^{1/2}v_{n}^{Y/2},

𝒟¯i,2=OP​(Δn5/2−s′​vn1−Y−s′′​δ−1)+OP​(Δ2​vn2−2​Y).\overline{\mathcal{D}}_{i,2}=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/2-s^{\prime}}v_{n}^{1-Y-s^{\prime\prime}}\delta^{-1})+O_{P}(\Delta^{2}v_{n}^{2-2Y}).

The second term above is OP​(Δn3​vn−Y−2)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-Y-2}) because vn≪Δn1/(4−Y)v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/(4-Y)}. For the first term above to be oP​(Δn34​vn4−Y2)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}), we need:

Δn5/2−s′​vn1−Y−s′′​δ−1≪Δn34​vn4−Y2⇔Δn74−s′​vn−1−Y2−s′′≪δ,\displaystyle\Delta_{n}^{5/2-s^{\prime}}v_{n}^{1-Y-s^{\prime\prime}}\delta^{-1}\ll\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}\quad\iff\quad\Delta_{n}^{\frac{7}{4}-s^{\prime}}v_{n}^{-1-\frac{Y}{2}-s^{\prime\prime}}\ll\delta, (64)

which is compatible with (63) if Δn74​vn−1−Y2≪Δn−14​vn1+Y2\Delta_{n}^{\frac{7}{4}}v_{n}^{-1-\frac{Y}{2}}\ll\Delta_{n}^{-\frac{1}{4}}v_{n}^{1+\frac{Y}{2}} or, equivalently, Δn22+Y≪vn\Delta_{n}^{\frac{2}{2+Y}}\ll v_{n}. The latter obviously holds for all 0<Y<20<Y<2 since vn≫Δn12v_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}}. On the other hand, (63) is also compatible with the constraint δ≫Δn1/2​vnY/2\delta\gg\Delta_{n}^{1/2}v_{n}^{Y/2} required for [3, eq. (B.19)] since Δn1/2≪vn\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\ll v_{n}. The remaining part of the proof is the same as Lemma 3 in [3]. To carry the expansion of [3, Lemma 3], with the updated error OP​(Δn3​vn−2−Y)+oP​(Δn34​vn4−Y2)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3}v_{n}^{-2-Y})+o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{\frac{3}{4}}v_{n}^{\frac{4-Y}{2}}), to the most general process XX, it remains to establish an appropriate analog of Lemma 5 in [3]. This is detailed in Section A.1.4 below.

A.1.4 Analog of Lemma 5 in [3]

With r=r0∈(0,Y∧1)r=r_{0}\in(0,Y\wedge 1), Lemma 5 in [3] states that for any α≥1\alpha\geq 1,

|(Δi​X)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}−(Δi​X′)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X′|≤vn}|\displaystyle|(\Delta_{i}X)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}-(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}|
=OP​(Δn​vn2​p−α​r0)+OP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y−1+α).\displaystyle\quad=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-\alpha r_{0}})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y-1+\alpha}). (65)

The above equation still holds under the hypotheses of Proposition 1. To establish (14), it is further required that the above terms are oP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}), which can be ensured by choosing α\alpha close to 1 from above, since r0<Yr_{0}<Y, Δn​vn−r1​α≪Δn​vn−2≪1\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-r_{1}\alpha}\ll\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-2}\ll 1 under our condition r0∈[0,Y∧1)r_{0}\in[0,Y\wedge 1).

For (15) and (16), the corresponding requirements for the errors in (65) are oP​(Δn5/4)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{5/4}) and oP​(Δn3/4​vn2−Y/2)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}), respectively. Since Δn3/4​vn2−Y/2≪Δn5/4\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}\ll\Delta_{n}^{5/4} under vn≪Δn1/(4−Y)v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/(4-Y)}, it suffices to establish that the terms are oP​(Δn3/4​vn2−Y/2)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}), which occurs if the following hold:

  1. 1.

    Δn​vn2−α​r0≪Δn3/4​vn2−Y/2\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-\alpha r_{0}}\ll\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}, which holds if α<(Y+1)/(2​r0)\alpha<(Y+1)/(2r_{0}). This is obtained by observing Δn​vn2−α​r0≪Δn3/4​vn2−Y/2⇔Δn≪vn4​α​r0−2​Y\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-\alpha r_{0}}\ll\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}\Leftrightarrow\Delta_{n}\ll v_{n}^{4\alpha r_{0}-2Y} and, since we required Δn1/2≪vn\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\ll v_{n}, we only need to impose that vn2≪vn4​α​r0−2​Yv_{n}^{2}\ll v_{n}^{4\alpha r_{0}-2Y}, which is satisfied if α<(Y+1)/(2​r0)\alpha<(Y+1)/(2r_{0}).

  2. 2.

    Δn​vn2−Y−1+α≪Δn3/4​vn2−Y/2\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y-1+\alpha}\ll\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2} if α>1/2+Y/2\alpha>1/2+Y/2. This is obtained by observing Δn​vn2−Y−1+α≪Δn3/4​vn2−Y/2⇔Δn1/(2​Y+4−4​α)≪vn\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y-1+\alpha}\ll\Delta_{n}^{3/4}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}\Leftrightarrow\Delta_{n}^{1/(2Y+4-4\alpha)}\ll v_{n} and comparing Δn1/(2​Y+4−4​α)≪Δn1/2\Delta_{n}^{1/(2Y+4-4\alpha)}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/2}.

In conclusion, we need to pick α\alpha such that

1+Y2<α<1+Y2​r0,\frac{1+Y}{2}<\alpha<\frac{1+Y}{2r_{0}},

which is always possible given r0∈[0,1)r_{0}\in[0,1).

A.1.5 Proof of (17)

As with the proofs of (15) and (16), we proceed in two steps: first we show (17) for the process X′X^{\prime} defined in (58) and then, we show the analog of Lemma 5 in [3]; i.e., we show that, for any real number p>1p>1,

|(Δi​X)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}−(Δi​X′)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X′|≤vn}|=OP​(σti−12​p​Δnp)+OP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y).|(\Delta_{i}X)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}-(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}|=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}). (66)

Note that (66) allows non-integer moment and does not directly follow from Lemma 5 in [3].

For simplicity, we re-use the notation in (A), except with Jt∞J_{t}^{\infty} in place of JtJ_{t}. To prove (17), we need to show that, for any p>1p>1, the following two estimates hold:

𝔼i−1​|xi​𝟏{|xi|≤vn}|2​p=OP​(σti−12​p​Δnp)+OP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y),\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2p}=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}), (67)

and

𝔼i−1​|(Δi​X)​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}|2​p−𝔼i−1​|xi​𝟏{|xi|≤vn}|2​p=OP​(σti−12​p​Δnp)+OP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y).\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big|(\Delta_{i}X)\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2p}-\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2p}=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}). (68)

We begin with (67) and proceed along the lines of Proposition 3 in [4]. It suffices to show

𝔼i−1​(|σti−1​Δi​W+χti−1​Δi​J∞|2​p​𝟏{|σti−1​Δi​W+χti−1​Δi​J∞|≤vn})=OP​(σti−12​p​Δnp)+OP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y).\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big)=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}). (69)

Note that

𝔼i−1​(|σti−1​Δi​W+χti−1​Δi​J∞|2​p​𝟏{|σti−1​Δi​W+χti−1​Δi​J∞|≤vn})\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(\big|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}\big|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big)
≲𝔼i−1​|σti−1​Δi​W|2​p+𝔼i−1​(|Δi​J∞|2​p​𝟏{|σti−1​Δi​W+χti−1​Δi​J∞|≤vn}),\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W|^{2p}+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big),

and, by self-similarity, 𝔼i−1​|σti−1​Δi​W|2​p=OP​(σti−12​p​Δnp)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W|^{2p}=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p}). Thus, to show (69), it suffices that

An:=𝔼i−1​(|χti−1​Δi​J∞|2​p​𝟏{|σti−1​Δi​W+χti−1​Δi​J∞|≤vn})≲Δn​vn2​p−Y+Δnp.A_{n}:=\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big)\lesssim\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}+\Delta_{n}^{p}.

Note that 𝟏{|σti−1​Δi​W+χti−1​Δi​J∞|≤vn}≤𝟏|σti−1​Δi​W|≤vn​𝟏{|χti−1​Δi​J∞|≤2​vn}+𝟏|σti−1​Δi​W|>vn\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\leq\mathbf{1}_{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W|\leq v_{n}}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq 2v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}}. Then we may further write

An\displaystyle A_{n} ≤𝔼i−1​(|χti−1​Δi​J∞|2​p​𝟏{|χti−1​Δi​J∞|≤2​vn})+𝔼i−1​(|χti−1​Δi​J∞|2​p​𝟏{|σti−1​Δi​W+χti−1​Δi​J∞|≤vn}⋅𝟏|σti−1​Δi​W|>vn)\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq 2v_{n}\}}\big)+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\cdot\mathbf{1}_{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}}\big)
=:V1+V2.\displaystyle=:V_{1}+V_{2}.

For V1V_{1}, by (B.38) in [4], we obtain that

V1≲Δn​vn2​p−Y+Δnp.\displaystyle V_{1}\lesssim\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}+\Delta_{n}^{p}. (70)

For V2V_{2}, let KK be the smallest positive integer such that K>pK>p. And further assume σti−1≠0\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\neq 0, otherwise V2=0V_{2}=0. By Hölder’s inequality and (B.37) in [4], we have

V2\displaystyle V_{2} ≤𝔼i−1​(|χti−1​Δi​J∞|2​K​𝟏{|σti−1​Δi​W+χti−1​Δi​J∞|≤vn})pK​P​(|σti−1​Δi​W|>vn)K−pK\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|^{2K}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J^{\infty}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big)^{\frac{p}{K}}P\big(|\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}\big)^{\frac{K-p}{K}}
≲(Δn​vn2​K−Y+Δn2​vn2​K−Y−2+Δn2​K−Y/2)pK​exp⁡(−K−p2​K​σti−12​(Δn−1​vn2)),\displaystyle\lesssim(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2K-Y}+\Delta_{n}^{2}v_{n}^{2K-Y-2}+\Delta_{n}^{2K-Y/2})^{\frac{p}{K}}\exp\Big(-\frac{K-p}{2K{\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}}}(\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{2})\Big), (71)

which vanishes faster than any power of Δn\Delta_{n} given Δn−1​vn2≫Δn−2​s\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{2}\gg{\Delta_{n}^{-2s}} and hence V2=oP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)V_{2}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}). Combining (70) and (71) yields (69).

Now we proceed to establish (68). Note that for any q>1q>1 and real numbers a,ba,b, we have111111Indeed, for some θ∈(0,1)\theta\in(0,1), ||b|q−|a|q|=q​||b|−|a||​|(θ​|a|+(1−θ)​|b|)|q−1≤q​||b|−|a||​(|a|q−1+|b|q−1)||b|^{q}-|a|^{q}|=q||b|-|a|||(\theta|a|+(1-\theta)|b|)|^{q-1}\leq q||b|-|a||(|a|^{q-1}+|b|^{q-1}) because clearly θ​|a|+(1−θ)​|b|≤max⁡{|a|,|b|}\theta|a|+(1-\theta)|b|\leq\max\{|a|,|b|\}.

||a|q−|b|q|≤q​||a|−|b||​(|a|q−1+|b|q−1).\displaystyle\big||a|^{q}-|b|^{q}\big|\leq q\big||a|-|b|\big|\big(|a|^{q-1}+|b|^{q-1}\big). (72)

We utilize the inequality (72) to bound (68) by taking q=2​pq=2p, a=(Δi​X)​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}a=(\Delta_{i}X)\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}, and b=xi​𝟏{|xi|≤vn}b=x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}. Also, recalling that Δi​X=xi+εi\Delta_{i}X=x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}, we have

||a|−|b||≤|a−b|≤|εi​|𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}+|​xi|​(𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn<|xi|}+𝟏{|xi|≤vn<|xi+εi|}).\big||a|-|b|\big|\leq|a-b|\leq|\varepsilon_{i}|\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}+|x_{i}|(\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}|\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\}}).

Using the two inequalities above together with |x+ε|2​p−1≤22​p−2​(|x|2​p−1+|ε|2​p−2)|x+\varepsilon|^{2p-1}\leq 2^{2p-2}(|x|^{2p-1}+|\varepsilon|^{2p-2}), we obtain:

𝔼i−1​|(Δi​X)​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}|2​p−𝔼i−1​|xi​𝟏{|xi|≤vn}|2​p\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big|(\Delta_{i}X)\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2p}-\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2p}
≲𝔼i−1{[|εi𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}|+|xi|(𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn<|xi|}+𝟏{|xi|≤vn<|xi+εi|})]\displaystyle\lesssim\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\Big\{\big[|\varepsilon_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|+|x_{i}|(\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}|\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\}})\big]
⋅[|xi+εi|2​p−1𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}+|xi|2​p−1𝟏{|xi|≤vn}]}\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\cdot\big[{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|}^{2p-1}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}+{|x_{i}|}^{2p-1}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big]\Big\}
≲𝔼i−1​|εi2​p​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}|+𝔼i−1​|εi​xi2​p−1​(𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}+𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn,|xi|≤vn})|\displaystyle\lesssim\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\varepsilon_{i}^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big|\varepsilon_{i}x_{i}^{2p-1}(\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n},|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}})\big|
+𝔼i−1​|xi2​p​(𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn<|xi|}+𝟏{|xi|≤vn≤|xi+εi|})​(𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}+𝟏{|xi|≤vn})|\displaystyle\quad+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big|x_{i}^{2p}(\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}|\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\}})(\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}})\big|
=𝔼i−1​|εi2​p​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}|+𝔼i−1​|εi​xi2​p−1​(𝟏|xi+εi|≤vn<|xi|+𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn,|xi|≤vn})|\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\varepsilon_{i}^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big|\varepsilon_{i}x_{i}^{2p-1}(\mathbf{1}_{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}|}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n},|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}})\big|
+𝔼i−1​|xi2​p​(𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn<|xi|}+𝟏{|xi|≤vn≤|xi+εi|})|\displaystyle\quad+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big|x_{i}^{2p}(\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}|\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\}})\big|
=:Ri,1+Ri,2+Ri,3.\displaystyle=:R_{i,1}+R_{i,2}+R_{i,3}. (73)

By (57), we obtain Ri,1=OP​(Δn1+p)=oP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)R_{i,1}=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{1+p})=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}) given Δn1/2≪vn\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\ll v_{n} and Y>0Y>0. Now we analyze Ri,3R_{i,3}. For 𝔼i−1​|xi|2​p​𝟏{|xi|≤vn≤|xi+εi|}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\}} we can directly apply (67) and consequently 𝔼i−1​|xi|2​p​𝟏{|xi|≤vn≤|xi+εi|}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\}} is of order OP​(σti−12​p​Δnp)+OP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y){O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})}. For the remaining term in Ri,3R_{i,3}, we consider the following decomposition:

𝔼i−1​|xi​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn≤|xi|}|2​p\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}|\}}|^{2p} ≤𝔼i−1​|xi​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn≤|xi|}⋅𝟏{|εi|≤|vn|}|2​p+𝔼i−1​|xi​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn≤|xi|}⋅𝟏{|εi|>|vn|}|2​p\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}|\}}\cdot\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq|v_{n}|\}}|^{2p}+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}|\}}\cdot\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>|v_{n}|\}}|^{2p}
=:D~i,1+D~i,2.\displaystyle=:\tilde{D}_{i,1}+\tilde{D}_{i,2}.

Note that |xi+εi|≤vn|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} and |εi|≤|vn||\varepsilon_{i}|\leq|v_{n}| implies |xi|≤2​vn|x_{i}|\leq 2v_{n} and, we can again, simply apply (67) to obtain D~i,1≲Δn​vn2​p−Y+Δnp\tilde{D}_{i,1}\lesssim\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}+\Delta_{n}^{p}. Regarding D~i,2\tilde{D}_{i,2}, for some q>1q>1, Hölder’s inequality yields

𝔼i−1​|xi​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn≤|xi|}⋅𝟏{|εi|>|2​vn|}|2​p≤(𝔼i−1​|xi​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}|2​p​q)1/q​P​(|εi|>|2​vn|)(q−1)/q,\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\leq|x_{i}|\}}\cdot\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>|2v_{n}|\}}|^{2p}\leq\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2pq}\big)^{1/q}P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>|2v_{n}|)^{(q-1)/q},

which is of order oP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}) by taking qq such that p​qpq is integer, as 𝔼i−1​|xi​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}|2​p​q\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{2pq} is finite by (14), while P​(|εi|>|2​vn|)P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>|2v_{n}|) vanishes faster than any power of Δn\Delta_{n} by (57) given that Δnβ≪vn\Delta_{n}^{\beta}\ll v_{n} with β<12\beta<\frac{1}{2}. Combining D~i,1\tilde{D}_{i,1} and D~i,2\tilde{D}_{i,2}, we obtain Ri,3=OP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)R_{i,3}=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}).

Lastly, we turn to Ri,2R_{i,2} in (73). By Hölder’s inequality,

Ri,2\displaystyle R_{i,2} ≤(𝔼i−1​|εi|2​p)12​p​(𝔼i−1​|xi|2​p​𝟏|xi+εi|≤vn<|xi|)2​p−12​p+(𝔼i−1​|εi|2​p)12​p​(𝔼i−1​|xi|2​p​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn,|xi|≤vn})2​p−12​p\displaystyle\leq\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\varepsilon_{i}|^{2p}\big)^{\frac{1}{2p}}\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}<|x_{i}|}\big)^{\frac{2p-1}{2p}}+\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\varepsilon_{i}|^{2p}\big)^{\frac{1}{2p}}\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n},|x_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\big)^{\frac{2p-1}{2p}}
≲Δn1+p2​p​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)2​p−12​p+Δn1+p2​p​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)2​p−12​p,\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1+p}{2p}}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})^{\frac{2p-1}{2p}}+\Delta_{n}^{\frac{1+p}{2p}}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})^{\frac{2p-1}{2p}},

where the second line follows from (57), (67), and the bound we obtained for D~i,2\tilde{D}_{i,2} above. We can then conclude that Ri,2=oP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)R_{i,2}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}) as Δn1+p=oP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)\Delta_{n}^{1+p}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}).

Combining the results for Ri,1R_{i,1}, Ri,2R_{i,2}, and Ri,3R_{i,3}, we establish (68) and conclude the proof of (17) for Xt′X_{t}^{\prime}. More specifically, we have obtained

𝔼​(|Δi​X′|2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}|ℱi−1)=OP​(σti−12​p​Δnp)+OP​(Cp,ti−1​Δn​vn2​p−Y).\mathbb{E}\big(|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\big)=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2{p}}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(C_{{p},t_{i-1}}\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2{p}-Y}). (74)

Now we will show (66). Following the idea of Lemma 5 in [3], for any p>1p>1, let

D2​p:=|(Δi​X)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}−(Δi​X′)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X′|≤vn}|.D_{2p}:=\left|(\Delta_{i}X)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}-(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}\right|.

Denote Vt=Xt−Xt′V_{t}=X_{t}-X_{t}^{\prime}, where recalling J0J^{0} as defined in (60),

Vt:=∫0t∫δ(s,z)𝔭(ds,dz)+∫0tχsdJs0=:Yt+∫0tχsdJs0.V_{t}:=\int_{0}^{t}\int\delta(s,z)\mathfrak{p}(ds,dz)+\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s}dJ_{s}^{0}=:Y_{t}+\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s}dJ_{s}^{0}.

For any fixed p≥1p\geq 1, by decomposing the indicator 𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}} and 𝟏{|Δi​X′|≤vn}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}, we can obtain

D2​p\displaystyle D_{2p} =|(Δi​X)2​p−(Δi​X′)2​p|​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn,|Δi​X′|≤vn}\displaystyle=\left|(\Delta_{i}X)^{2p}-(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\right|\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}
+(Δi​X)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn,|Δi​X′|>vn}\displaystyle\quad+(\Delta_{i}X)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|>v_{n}\}}
+(Δi​X′)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X|>vn,|Δi​X′|≤vn}\displaystyle\quad+(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|>v_{n},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}
=:T1+T2+T3.\displaystyle=:T_{1}+T_{2}+T_{3}.

We start with T1T_{1}. By Taylor expansion of (x′+v)2​p(x^{\prime}+v)^{2p} at v=0v=0, we obtain

|(x′+v)2​p−(x′)2​p|≤K​|v|​(|x′|2​p−1+|v|2​p−1),|(x^{\prime}+v)^{2p}-(x^{\prime})^{2p}|\leq K|v|\left(|x^{\prime}|^{2p-1}+|v|^{2p-1}\right),

which applied to T1T_{1} yields

T1≤K​(|Δi​V|2​p+|Δi​V|​|Δi​X′|2​p−1)​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn,|Δi​X′|≤vn}.T_{1}\leq K\left(|\Delta_{i}V|^{2p}+|\Delta_{i}V||\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|^{2p-1}\right)\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}. (75)

We first bound Δi​V\Delta_{i}V. By Corollary 2.1.9 in [10], for each l≥1l\geq 1 and some constant K>0K>0, we have:

𝔼i−1​(|Δi​Yvn∧1|l)≤K​Δn​vn−r0.\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left(\left|\frac{\Delta_{i}Y}{v_{n}}\wedge 1\right|^{l}\right)\leq K\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-r_{0}}. (76)

On the other hand, since J0J^{0} is compound Poisson, if we let N0​(d​s,d​x)N^{0}(ds,dx) be its jump measure, for some K>0K>0, we have

𝔼i−1​(|1vn​∫ti−1tiχs​𝑑Js0∧1|p)≤ℙ​(N0​([ti−1,ti],ℝ)>0)≤K​Δn.\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left(\left|\frac{1}{v_{n}}\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}\chi_{s}dJ_{s}^{0}\wedge 1\right|^{p}\right)\leq\mathbb{P}(N^{0}([t_{i-1},t_{i}],\mathbb{R})>0)\leq K\Delta_{n}.

Together with (76), we obtain

𝔼i−1​(|Δi​V|l​𝟏{|Δi​V|≤vn})≤K​Δn​vnl−r0.\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left(|\Delta_{i}V|^{l}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}V|\leq v_{n}\}}\right)\leq K\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{l-r_{0}}.

Since |x+v|≤vn|x+v|\leq v_{n} and |x|≤vn|x|\leq v_{n} imply |v|≤2​vn|v|\leq 2v_{n}, applying the above inequality to T1T_{1} we get:

𝔼i−1​T1≤K​(𝔼i−1​[|Δi​V|2​p​𝟏{|Δi​V|≤2​vn}]+vn2​p−1​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​V|​𝟏{|Δi​V|≤2​vn}])≤K​Δn​vn2​p−r0.\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{1}\leq K\left(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|\Delta_{i}V|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}V|\leq 2v_{n}\}}]+v_{n}^{2p-1}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|\Delta_{i}V|\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}V|\leq 2v_{n}\}}]\right)\leq K\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-r_{0}}. (77)

Now we move to T2T_{2}. For some α≥1\alpha\geq 1 to be later specified, we may decompose T2T_{2} as follows:

T2=|ΔiX|2​p𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn,|Δi​X′|>vn+vnα}+|ΔiX|2​p𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn<|Δi​X′|≤vn+vnα}=:T2′+T2′′T_{2}=|\Delta_{i}X|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|>v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}+|\Delta_{i}X|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}<|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}=:T_{2}^{\prime}+T_{2}^{\prime\prime} (78)

Notice that |x′+v|≤vn|x^{\prime}+v|\leq v_{n} and |x′|>vn+vnα|x^{\prime}|>v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha} implies |v|>vnα|v|>v_{n}^{\alpha}. For T2′T_{2}^{\prime} we obtain the bound

𝔼i−1​T2′\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{2}^{\prime} ≤vn2​p​ℙi−1​(|Δi​V|>vnα,|Δi​X′|>vn+vnα)\displaystyle\leq v_{n}^{2p}\mathbb{P}_{i-1}(|\Delta_{i}V|>v_{n}^{\alpha},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|>v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha})
≤K​vn2​p​(Δn​vn−α​r0),\displaystyle\leq Kv_{n}^{2p}\left(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{-\alpha r_{0}}\right), (79)

which follows from the bound ℙi−1​(|Δi​V|>u)≤𝔼i−1​(|Δi​Vu∧1|l)≤K​Δn​u−r0.\mathbb{P}_{i-1}(|\Delta_{i}V|>u)\leq\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left(\left|\frac{\Delta_{i}V}{u}\wedge 1\right|^{l}\right)\leq K\Delta_{n}u^{-r_{0}}. For T2′′T_{2}^{\prime\prime}, notice that |x′+v|≤vn|x^{\prime}+v|\leq v_{n} and |x′|≤vn+vnα|x^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha} implies |v|≤2​vn+vnα|v|\leq 2v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}. We have:

𝔼i−1​T2′′\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{2}^{\prime\prime} =𝔼i−1​[|Δi​X|2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn<|Δi​X′|≤vn+vnα}]\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}X|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}<|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}\right]
≤K​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​X′|2​p+|Δi​V|2​p]​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn<|Δi​X′|≤vn+vnα}\displaystyle\leq K\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|^{2p}+|\Delta_{i}V|^{2p}\right]\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}<|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}
≤𝔼i−1​|Δi​X′|2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X′|≤vn+vnα}+OP​(Δn​vn2​p−r0).\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-r_{0}}). (80)

Since α≥1\alpha\geq 1, by (74), we obtain

𝔼i−1​|Δi​X′|2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X′|≤vn+vnα}=OP​(σti−12​p​Δnp)+OP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y),\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}+v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}),

which combined with (79) implies

𝔼i−1​T2=OP​(σti−12​p​Δnp)+OP​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)+OP​(Δn​vn2​p−α​r0).\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{2}=O_{P}(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})+O_{P}(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-\alpha r_{0}}).

Lastly for T3T_{3}, similarly we may write

T3=(Δi​X′)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​X|>vn,|Δi​X′|≤vn−vnα}+(Δi​X′)2​p​𝟏{vn−vnα<|Δi​X′|≤vn}=T3′+T3′′.T_{3}=(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|>v_{n},|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}-v_{n}^{\alpha}\}}+(\Delta_{i}X^{\prime})^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{v_{n}-v_{n}^{\alpha}<|\Delta_{i}X^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}\}}=T_{3}^{\prime}+T_{3}^{\prime\prime}.

Since |x′+v|>vn|x^{\prime}+v|>v_{n} and |x′|≤vn−vnα|x^{\prime}|\leq v_{n}-v_{n}^{\alpha} imply |v|>vnα|v|>v_{n}^{\alpha}, the same arguments as for T2′,T2′′T_{2}^{\prime},T_{2}^{\prime\prime} apply to T3′,T3′′T_{3}^{\prime},T_{3}^{\prime\prime}. In conclusion, we have the following bound

𝔼i−1​T1+𝔼i−1​T2+𝔼i−1​T3≲Δn​vn2​p−r0+Δn​vn2​p−α​r0+σti−12​p​Δnp+Δn​vn2​p−Y.\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{1}+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{2}+\mathbb{E}_{i-1}T_{3}\ \lesssim\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-r_{0}}+\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-\alpha r_{0}}+\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p}+\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}. (81)

To show (66), it suffices to show

Δn​vn2​p−r0+Δn​vn2​p−α​r0≲σti−12​p​Δnp+Δn​vn2​p−Y.\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-r_{0}}+\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-\alpha r_{0}}\lesssim\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2p}\Delta_{n}^{p}+\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}.

Indeed, notice that r∈(0,Y∧1)r\in(0,Y\wedge 1). It follows that Δn​vn2​p−r0=o​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-r_{0}}=o(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}). Thus, if we take α=Y2+Y2​r\alpha=\frac{Y}{2}+\frac{Y}{2r}, we obtain α​r<Y\alpha r<Y, and Since Y<2Y<2, we have

Δn​vn2​p−α​r0=o​(Δn​vn2​p−Y),\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-\alpha r_{0}}=o(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y}),

which concludes the proof.

A.2 Proofs of some technical identities in Theorem 1

In view of (17) and Lemma 5 in [3], in the following, we assume that the discontinuous part of XX is comprosed only of Lévy-driven term of infinite variation and may omit the jumps of finite variation. Specifically, we may assume that XX takes the form:

Xt=∫0tbs​𝑑s+∫0tσs​𝑑Ws+∫0tχs​𝑑Js.X_{t}=\int_{0}^{t}b_{s}ds+\int_{0}^{t}\sigma_{s}dW_{s}+\int_{0}^{t}\chi_{s}dJ_{s}.
Proof of (32).

As in [3], the key idea is to discretize the integrals involved in YiY_{i} as in (A). We treat each term in the expansion Δi​X2=(xi+εi)2=xi2+2​xi​εi+εi2\Delta_{i}X^{2}=(x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i})^{2}=x_{i}^{2}+2x_{i}\varepsilon_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}^{2} separately. For the third term εi2\varepsilon_{i}^{2}, by Cauchy-Schwarz, we obtain

mn|∑i=1nKmn​Δn(ti−1−τ)𝔼i−1εi2𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}(ΔiM))|2\displaystyle m_{n}\Big|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\varepsilon_{i}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}(\Delta_{i}M)\big)\Big|^{2}
≤mn​|∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​(εi4)1/2​𝔼i−1​(Δi​M2)1/2|2\displaystyle\quad\leq m_{n}\Big|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\varepsilon_{i}^{4})^{1/2}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\Delta_{i}M^{2})^{1/2}\Big|^{2}
≤mn​(∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​(εi4))​(∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​(Δi​M2))\displaystyle\quad\leq m_{n}\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\varepsilon_{i}^{4})\Big)\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\Delta_{i}M^{2})\Big)
≤mn​Δn−1​OP​(Δn3)​OP​(1mn​Δn)=OP​(Δn)→0,\displaystyle\quad\leq m_{n}\Delta_{n}^{-1}O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3})O_{P}\big(\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\big)=O_{P}(\Delta_{n})\rightarrow 0, (82)

where the second inequality follows from Cauchy-Schwarz concerning the summation and the last inequality is due to (57) and

𝔼​(∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​(Δi​M2))≲1mn​Δn​∑i=1n𝔼i−1​(Δi​M2)=OP​(1mn​Δn),\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\Delta_{i}M^{2})\big)\lesssim\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\Delta_{i}M^{2})=O_{P}\big(\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\big), (83)

which follows from the boundedness of K​(⋅)K(\cdot) and the fact that MM is square integrable.

For the term 2​xi​εi2x_{i}\varepsilon_{i}, when |εi|>vn|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}, since Δn1/2/vn≪Δn1/2−β≪1\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/2-\beta}\ll 1, we can use Markov’s inequality to conclude that

P​(|εi|>vn)≤K​Δn1+(1/2−β)​r,P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n})\leq K\Delta_{n}^{1+(1/2-\beta)r},

for all r>Yr>Y according to (57). By taking large enough rr and applying Hölder’s inequality, for some q1,q2,q3>1q_{1},q_{2},q_{3}>1 and ∑i=131/qi=1/2\sum_{i=1}^{3}1/q_{i}=1/2, as 𝔼i−1​[|xi|q1]\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|x_{i}|^{q_{1}}] and 𝔼i−1​[|εi|q2]\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|\varepsilon_{i}|^{q_{2}}] is finite, we can show that

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|xi​εi|​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}​𝟏{|εi|>vn}​(Δi​M)]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|x_{i}\varepsilon_{i}|\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}\}}(\Delta_{i}M)\right]
≤mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|xi|q1]1/q1​𝔼i−1​[|εi|q2]1/q2​𝔼i−1​(Δi​M2)1/2​Pi−1​(|εi|>vn)1/q3\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|x_{i}|^{q_{1}}]^{1/q_{1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|\varepsilon_{i}|^{q_{2}}]^{1/q_{2}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\Delta_{i}M^{2})^{1/2}P_{i-1}(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n})^{1/{q_{3}}}
≤mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|xi|q1]1/q1​𝔼i−1​[|εi|q2]1/q2​𝔼i−1​(Δi​M2)1/2​Δn1/q3+(1/2−β)​r/q3\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|x_{i}|^{q_{1}}]^{1/q_{1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[|\varepsilon_{i}|^{q_{2}}]^{1/q_{2}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\Delta_{i}M^{2})^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/q_{3}+(1/2-\beta)r/q_{3}}
=oP​(1).\displaystyle\quad=o_{P}(1). (84)

When |εi|≤vn|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}, note |Δi​X|=|xi+εi|≤vn|\Delta_{i}X|=|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} implies that |xi|≤2​vn|x_{i}|\leq 2v_{n}. Then by applying Cauchy-Schwarz twice, we obtain:

mn​|∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|εi​xi|​𝟏{|xi|≤2​vn}​𝟏{|εi|≤vn}​|Δi​M|]|2\displaystyle m_{n}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\varepsilon_{i}x_{i}|\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq 2v_{n}\}}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}M|\right]\right|^{2}
≤mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[εi2​xi2​𝟏{|xi|≤2​vn}]​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​M)2]\displaystyle\leq m_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[\varepsilon_{i}^{2}x_{i}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq 2v_{n}\}}\right]\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]
≤mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​OP​(Δn3/2)​OP​(Δn)​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​M)2]\displaystyle\leq m_{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2})O_{P}(\Delta_{n})\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]
=mn​OP​(Δn3/2)​OP​(1mn​Δn)=OP​(Δn1/2)→𝑃0,\displaystyle=m_{n}O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2})O_{P}\big(\frac{1}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\big)=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{1/2})\xrightarrow{P}0, (85)

where in the second inequality we used Proposition 1 and (57), and in the last line, we used (83). All that remains is the term xi2x_{i}^{2}. Next, we want to show that

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[xi2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​(Δi​M)]→𝑃0.\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[x_{i}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}(\Delta_{i}M)\right]\xrightarrow{P}0. (86)

Firstly we start with replacing xix_{i} with bti−1​Δnb_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{n} in (86) and arbitrary MM. By the boundness of btb_{t}, KK and Cauchy-Schwarz, it follows that

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[bti−12​Δn2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​(Δi​M)]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[b_{t_{i-1}}^{2}\Delta_{n}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}(\Delta_{i}M)\right]
≲mn​Δn2mn​Δn​∑i=1n𝔼i−1​[(Δi​M)2]1/2\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}^{2}}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]^{1/2}
≤mn​Δn2mn​Δn3/2​(∑i=1n𝔼i−1​[(Δi​M)2])1/2→𝑃0,\displaystyle\leq\frac{\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}^{2}}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}^{3/2}}\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]\Big)^{1/2}\xrightarrow{P}0,

where we used ∑i=1n𝔼i−1​[(Δi​M)2]1/2≤Δn−1/2​(∑i=1n𝔼i−1​[(Δi​M)2])1/2\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]^{1/2}\leq\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]\Big)^{1/2}. Besides, by Cauchy-Schwarz twice, we also have

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[bti−1​Δn​x^i​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​(Δi​M)]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[b_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{n}\hat{x}_{i}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}(\Delta_{i}M)\right]
≲mn​Δnmn​Δn​(∑i=1n𝔼i−1​[x^i2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}])1/2​(∑i=1n𝔼i−1​[(Δi​M)2])1/2→𝑃0,\displaystyle\lesssim\frac{\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}}{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[\hat{x}_{i}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\right]\Big)^{1/2}\Big(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}M)^{2}\right]\Big)^{1/2}\xrightarrow{P}0,

Consequently, it is sufficient to prove (86) with xi=σti−1​Δi​W+χti−1​Δi​Jx_{i}=\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W+\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J.

Now we prove (86) when M=WM=W and we start with the case when xix_{i} is replaced with σti−1​Δi​W\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W. Similar to last inequality, by combining Cauchy-Schwarz and Proposition 1, we can write

mn​|∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​Δi​M]|\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}M\right]\right|
=mn​|∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)3​𝟏{|xi+εi|>vn}]|\displaystyle\quad=\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{3}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}\}}\right]\right|
≤mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​W|3​|xi+εi|]/vn\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}W|^{3}|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\right]/v_{n}
≤C​mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)6]1/2​𝔼i−1​[|xi+εi|2]1/2/vn\displaystyle\quad\leq C\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{6}\right]^{1/2}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|^{2}\right]^{1/2}/v_{n}
≤C​mn​n​Δn3/2​Δn1/2/vn→0,\displaystyle\quad\leq C\sqrt{m_{n}}n\Delta_{n}^{3/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}\rightarrow 0, (87)

where the last limit follows from mn​Δn→0m_{n}\Delta_{n}\rightarrow 0 and Δn1/2≪vn\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\ll v_{n}.

When xix_{i} and MM are replaced with χti−1​Δi​J\chi_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}J and M=WM=W in (86), we need to show that

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​|Δi​W|]→𝑃0.\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}W|\right]\xrightarrow{P}0. (88)

Note that when |Δi​W|>vn|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n} or |εi|>vn|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}, by Hölder’s inequality, and that P​(|εi|>vn)P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}) and P​(|Δi​W|>vn)P(|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}) decay faster than any power of Δn\Delta_{n} since Δn1/2/vn≪Δn1/2−β\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/2-\beta}, by similar techniques as in (A.2), we obtain

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​|Δi​W|​(𝟏{|Δi​W|>vn}+𝟏{|εi|>vn})]=oP​(1).\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}W|\left(\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}\}}\right)\right]=o_{P}(1). (89)

So we only focus on the case when |Δi​W|≤vn|\Delta_{i}W|\leq v_{n} and |εi|≤vn|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} with M=WM=W. Note that |xi+εi|≤vn|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} implies that |Δi​J|≤C​vn|\Delta_{i}J|\leq Cv_{n}, for some positive constant CC that we assume for simplicity is 1. In that case, for (88), it suffices to show

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤vn}​|Δi​W|]→𝑃0.\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}W|\right]\xrightarrow{P}0.

By Hölder’s inequality and Lemma 17 in [3], for any p,q>1p,q>1 such that 1/p+1/q=11/p+1/q=1,

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤vn}​|Δi​W|]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}W|\right]
≤mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤vn}]1/p​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​W|q]1/q\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}\right]^{1/p}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}W|^{q}\right]^{1/q}
≲mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)1/p​Δn1/2≲mn​n​Δn1/p+1/2​vn2−Y/p.\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau){(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})^{1/p}}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}n\Delta_{n}^{1/p+1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/p}.

So, making pp close to 1 (and qq large) and combining with (89), we get the convergence to 0 for (88) as mn​Δn→0m_{n}\Delta_{n}\rightarrow 0 and Δn1/2≪vn\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\ll v_{n}. Combining (A.2) and (88), we establish (86) when M=WM=W.

Next, we work on (86) with M=BM=B and we start with the case where xix_{i} is replaced with Δi​W\Delta_{i}W. Notice that

mn​|∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​Δi​B]|\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B\right]\right|
≤mn​|∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≥vn}​Δi​B]|\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\geq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B\right]\right|
+mn​|∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​Δi​B]|.\displaystyle\qquad+\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\Delta_{i}B\right]\right|.

For the first term, by Hölder’s inequality and Proposition 1, we have

mn​|∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​Δi​B]|\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B\right]\right|
≤C​mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)8]1/4​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​B)4]1/4​𝔼i−1​[|xi+εi|2]1/2/vn\displaystyle\leq C\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{8}\right]^{1/4}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}B)^{4}\right]^{1/4}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|^{2}\right]^{1/2}/v_{n}
≲mn​n​Δn3/2​Δn1/2/vn,\displaystyle\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}n\Delta_{n}^{3/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}, (90)

which vanishes under vn≫Δn1/2v_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{1/2} and mn​Δn→0m_{n}\Delta_{n}\rightarrow 0.

For the second term, given mn​Δn→0m_{n}\Delta_{n}\rightarrow 0, it suffices to show supi𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​Δi​B]=oP​(Δn3/2)\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\Delta_{i}B]=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}). Denote ρs=d​⟨W,B⟩s/d​s\rho_{s}=d\langle W,B\rangle_{s}/ds. ρs\rho_{s} is càdlàg and bounded on the interval [ti−1,ti][t_{i-1},t_{i}]. By Itô’s Lemma, Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, and Doob’s inequality, we have

supi𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​Δi​B]≲Δn3/2​supi𝔼i−1​(ρti−ρti−1)2.\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\Delta_{i}B]\lesssim\Delta_{n}^{3/2}\sup_{i}\sqrt{\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\rho_{t_{i}}-\rho_{t_{i-1}})^{2}}.

We notice that ρ\rho is right-continuous and uniformly bounded on [0,1][0,1] and thus, 𝔼i−1​(ρti−ρti−1)2→0\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\rho_{t_{i}}-\rho_{t_{i-1}})^{2}\rightarrow 0 Next, we check the case where xix_{i} and MM are replaced with Δi​J\Delta_{i}J and BB in (86), respectively. Similar to (88), we need to show that

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​|Δi​B|]→𝑃0.\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\right]\xrightarrow{P}0. (91)

Following the similar technique as in (88) and (A.2), note that when |Δi​W|>vn|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n} or |εi|>vn|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}, by Hölder’s inequality, and that P​(|εi|>vn)P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}) and P​(|Δi​W|>vn)P(|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}) decay faster than any power of Δn\Delta_{n} due to Δn1/2/vn≪Δn1/2−β\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/2-\beta}, we obtain

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​|Δi​B|​(𝟏{|Δi​W|>vn}+𝟏{|εi|>vn})]=oP​(1).\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\left(\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}\}}\right)\right]=o_{P}(1).

So, when |Δi​W|≤vn|\Delta_{i}W|\leq v_{n} and |εi|≤vn|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}, note |xi+εi|≤vn|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} implies that |Δi​J|≤C​vn|\Delta_{i}J|\leq Cv_{n}, for some positive constant CC. Then, for (91), it suffices to show

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤vn}​|Δi​B|]→𝑃0.\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\right]\xrightarrow{P}0.

By Hölder’s inequality and Lemma 17 in [3], for any p,q>1p,q>1 such that 1/p+1/q=11/p+1/q=1,

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤vn}​|Δi​B|]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\right]
≤mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤vn}]1/p​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​B|q]1/q\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}\right]^{1/p}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}B|^{q}\right]^{1/q}
≲mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​(Δn​vn2​p−Y)1/p​Δn1/2≲mn​n​Δn1/p+1/2​vn2−Y/p.\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})^{{1/p}}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}n\Delta_{n}^{1/p+1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/p}.

So, again, making pp close to 1 (and qq large), we get the convergence to 0, establishing (86) with M=BM=B.

Lastly, we want to show (86) for any bounded martingale MM which is orthogonal to WW. We first consider the case when xix_{i} is replaced with Δi​J\Delta_{i}J. As before, we can deal with the cases |Δi​W|>vn|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n} or εi>vn\varepsilon_{i}>v_{n}, since P​(|εi|>vn)P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}) and P​(|Δi​W|>vn)P(|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}) decays fast. So, we assume that |Δi​W|≤vn|\Delta_{i}W|\leq{v_{n}} and |εi|≤vn|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq{v_{n}}, so that, together with |xi+εi|≤vn|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}, we have |Δi​J|≤3​vn|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}. Then, we proceed as follows:

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​J|2​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤3​vn}​|Δi​M|]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J|^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}M|\right]
≤mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​J|4​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤3​vn}]1/2​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​M|2]1/2\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J|^{4}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}\}}\right]^{1/2}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}M|^{2}\right]^{1/2}
≤mn​(∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​J|4​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤3​vn}])1/2​(∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​M|2])1/2\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J|^{4}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}\}}\right]\right)^{1/2}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}M|^{2}\right]\right)^{1/2}
≲mn​(n​Δn​vn4−Y)1/2​(1mn1/2​Δn1/2)=(Δn−1​vn4−Y)1/2≪1,\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}(n\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{4-Y})^{1/2}\Big(\frac{1}{m_{n}^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}}\Big)=(\Delta_{n}^{-1}v_{n}^{4-Y})^{1/2}\ll 1,

which follows from vn≪Δn1/(4−Y)v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/(4-Y)}. For the cross-product σti−1​Δi​W​Δi​J\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W\Delta_{i}J, when expanding xi2x_{i}^{2}, and again assuming |Δi​J|≤3​vn|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}, we have, for any p>1p>1:

mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​J|​|Δi​W|​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤3​vn}​|Δi​M|]\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J||\Delta_{i}W|\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}M|\right]
≤mn​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​J|2​p​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤3​vn}]12​p​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​W|2​pp−1]p−12​p​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​M|2]12\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}\}}\right]^{\frac{1}{2p}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}W|^{\frac{2p}{p-1}}\right]^{\frac{p-1}{2p}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}M|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}
≤mn​Δn1/2​(∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​(𝔼i−1​[|Δi​J|2​p​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤3​vn}])1/p)1/2\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J|^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq 3v_{n}\}}\right]\big)^{1/p}\right)^{1/2}
×(∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​M|2])1/2\displaystyle\qquad\times\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}M|^{2}\right]\right)^{1/2}
≲mn1/2​Δn1/2​(n​Δn1/p​vn2−Y/p)1/2​(1mn1/2​Δn1/2).\displaystyle\quad\lesssim m_{n}^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}(n\Delta_{n}^{1/p}v_{n}^{2-Y/p})^{1/2}\Big(\frac{1}{m_{n}^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}}\Big).

By taking pp close to 1, the above vanishes given vn→0v_{n}\rightarrow 0. Finally, we consider the case when xix_{i} is replaced with σti−1​Δi​W\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W. Note that

(Δi​W)2=2​∫ti−1ti(Ws−Wti−1)​𝑑Ws+Δn,(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}=2\int_{t_{i-1}}^{t_{i}}(W_{s}-W_{t_{i-1}})dW_{s}+\Delta_{n},

and since MM is orthogonal to WW,

𝔼i−1​[((Δi​W)2−Δn)​Δi​M]=0,\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[\left((\Delta_{i}W)^{2}-\Delta_{n}\right)\Delta_{i}M\right]=0,

which implies that 𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​Δi​M]=0\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\Delta_{i}M\right]=0. Thus, for any p,q>0p,q>0 such that 1/p+1/q=1/21/p+1/q=1/2, by orthogonality between MM and WW, we have

mn​|∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​Δi​M]|\displaystyle\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}M\right]\right|
=mn​|−∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​σti−12​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≥vn}​Δi​M]|\displaystyle\quad=\sqrt{m_{n}}\left|-\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\sigma^{2}_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\geq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}M\right]\right|
≤mn​vn−1​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​W|2​|xi+εi|​|Δi​M|]\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}v_{n}^{-1}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}W|^{2}|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}||\Delta_{i}M|\right]
≤mn​vn−1​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​W|2​p]1/p​𝔼i−1​[|xi+εi|q]1/q​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​M|2]1/2\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}v_{n}^{-1}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}W|^{2p}\right]^{1/p}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|^{q}\right]^{1/q}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}M|^{2}\right]^{1/2}
≤mn​vn−1​(∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​W|2​p]2/p​𝔼i−1​[|xi+εi|q]2/q)1/2\displaystyle\quad\leq\sqrt{m_{n}}v_{n}^{-1}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}W|^{2p}\right]^{2/p}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|^{q}\right]^{2/q}\right)^{1/2}
×(∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​M|2])1/2\displaystyle\qquad\times\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}M|^{2}\right]\right)^{1/2}
≲mn​vn−1​(n​Δn2​Δn2/q)1/2×(1mn1/2​Δn1/2)\displaystyle\quad\lesssim\sqrt{m_{n}}v_{n}^{-1}\left(n\Delta_{n}^{2}\Delta_{n}^{2/q}\right)^{1/2}\times\Big(\frac{1}{m_{n}^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}}\Big) (92)
≤(mn​Δn)1/2​Δn1/q​vn−1×(1mn1/2​Δn1/2)=Δn1/q​vn−1,\displaystyle\quad\leq(m_{n}\Delta_{n})^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/q}v_{n}^{-1}\times\Big(\frac{1}{m_{n}^{1/2}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}}\Big)=\Delta_{n}^{1/q}v_{n}^{-1},

which vanishes by taking qq close enough to 2 and pp large enough given that vn≫Δnβv_{n}\gg\Delta_{n}^{\beta} with β<1/2\beta<1/2. ♢\diamondsuit

Proof of (33).

Recall that (Δi​X)2=xi2+2​xi​εi+εi2.(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}=x_{i}^{2}+2x_{i}\varepsilon_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}^{2}. We analyze 𝔼i−1​((xi+2​xi​εi+εi2)​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}​Δi​B)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big((x_{i}+2x_{i}\varepsilon_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}^{2})\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B\big) term by term. For the third term, by Cauchy-Schwarz and (57), we have

supi|𝔼i−1​(εi2​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}​Δi​B)|≤supi(𝔼i−1​εi4​𝔼i−1​Δi​B2)1/2=OP​(Δn3/2)​(Δn1/2)=oP​(Δn3/2).\displaystyle\sup_{i}{|\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(\varepsilon_{i}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B\big)|}\leq\sup_{i}\big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\varepsilon_{i}^{4}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\Delta_{i}B^{2}\big)^{1/2}=O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2})(\Delta_{n}^{1/2})=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}). (93)

For the second term, similar to (A.2), when |εi|>vn|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}, by Markov’s inequality and (57), we can obtain that

P​(|εi|>vn)≤K​Δn1+(1/2−β)​rP(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n})\leq K\Delta_{n}^{1+(1/2-\beta)r}

for all r>0r>0. By Holder’s inequality, for p1,p2,p3>1p_{1},p_{2},p_{3}>1 such that ∑i=131/pi=1\sum_{i=1}^{3}1/p_{i}=1, we may write

supi|𝔼i−1​(εi​xi​𝟏|Δi​X|≤vn,|εi|>vn​Δi​B)|≤supi𝔼i−1​|εip1|1/p1​𝔼i−1​|xip2​𝟏{|Δi​X|≤vn}|1/p2​P​(|εi|>vn)1/p3.\displaystyle\sup_{i}|\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big({\varepsilon_{i}x_{i}}\mathbf{1}_{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n},|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}}\Delta_{i}B\big)|\leq\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|\varepsilon_{i}^{p_{1}}|^{1/p_{1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}|x_{i}^{p_{2}}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}\}}|^{1/p_{2}}P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n})^{1/p_{3}}.

As all the quantities on the right hand side are bounded but P​(|εi|>vn)P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}) vanishes faster than any fixed power of Δn\Delta_{n}. By taking large enough rr, we can obtain

supi|𝔼i−1​(|εi​xi|​𝟏|Δi​X|≤vn,|εi|>vn​Δi​B)|=oP​(Δn3/2).\sup_{i}|\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big(|\varepsilon_{i}x_{i}|\mathbf{1}_{|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n},{|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}}}\Delta_{i}B\big)|=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}).

Then what remains for the second term is the case that |εi|≤vn|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}. Since |εi|≤vn|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} and |Δi​X|≤vn|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n} implies |xi|≤2​vn|x_{i}|\leq 2v_{n}. By Cauchy-Schwarz, we obtain

supi𝔼i−1​[|εi​xi|​𝟏{|xi|≤2​vn}​𝟏{|εi|≤vn}​|Δi​B|]≤\displaystyle\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\varepsilon_{i}x_{i}|\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq 2v_{n}\}}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\right]\leq supi(𝔼i−1​[εi2​xi2​𝟏{|xi|≤2​vn}]​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​B)2])1/2\displaystyle\sup_{i}\Big(\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[\varepsilon_{i}^{2}x_{i}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}|\leq 2v_{n}\}}\right]\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}B)^{2}\right]\Big)^{1/2}
≤\displaystyle\leq OP​(Δn3/4)​OP​(Δn1/2)​Δn1/2=oP​(Δn3/2),\displaystyle O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/4})O_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{1/2})\Delta_{n}^{1/2}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}), (94)

Then what remains is the first term involving xi2x_{i}^{2}. We aim to show

supi𝔼i−1​[xi2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​Δi​B]=oP​(Δn3/2).\displaystyle\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[x_{i}^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B\right]=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}). (95)

We start by replacing xi2x_{i}^{2} with (σti−1​Δi​W)2(\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\Delta_{i}W)^{2}. Note that when |Δi​W|>vn|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n} or |εi|>vn|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}, by Hölder’s inequality, and that P​(|εi|>vn)P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}) and P​(|Δi​W|>vn)P(|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}) decay faster than any power of Δn\Delta_{n} since Δn1/2/vn≪Δn1/2−β\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/2-\beta}, using similar techniques as in (89) and the boundness of σ\sigma, we obtain

supi𝔼i−1​[σti−1​(Δi​W)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​|Δi​B|​(𝟏{|Δi​W|>vn}+𝟏{|εi|>vn})]=oP​(Δn3/2).\displaystyle\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[\sigma_{t_{i-1}}(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\left(\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}\}}\right)\right]=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}). (96)

And further notice that when |Δi​W|≤vn|\Delta_{i}W|\leq v_{n} and εi≤vn\varepsilon_{i}\leq v_{n}, |xi+εi|≤vn|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} imples |Δi​J|≤C​vn|\Delta_{i}J|\leq Cv_{n} for some positive constant CC that we assume for simplicity is 11. Then equivalently, we may write

supi𝔼i−1​[σti−1​(Δi​W)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​Δi​B​𝟏{|Δi​W|≤vn}​𝟏{|εi|≤vn}]\displaystyle\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[\sigma_{t_{i-1}}(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}W|\leq v_{n}\}}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}\right]
=\displaystyle= supi𝔼i−1​[σti−1​(Δi​W)2​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤vn}​Δi​B]\displaystyle\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[\sigma_{t_{i-1}}(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B\right]
=\displaystyle= supiσti−1​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​Δi​B]​P​(|Δi​J|≤vn).\displaystyle\sup_{i}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\Delta_{i}B]P(|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}). (97)

Then it suffices to show supi𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​Δi​B]=oP​(Δn3/2)\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\Delta_{i}B]=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}). Similar to how we handle the second term in (A.2), recall ρs=d​⟨W,B⟩s/d​s\rho_{s}=d\langle W,B\rangle_{s}/ds. By Itô’s Lemma, Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, and Doob’s inequality, we have

supi𝔼i−1​[(Δi​W)2​Δi​B]≲Δn3/2​supi𝔼i−1​(ρti−ρti−1)2.\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}[(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}\Delta_{i}B]\lesssim\Delta_{n}^{3/2}\sup_{i}\sqrt{\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\rho_{t_{i}}-\rho_{t_{i-1}})^{2}}.

Since ρ\rho is right-continuous and uniformly bounded on [0,1][0,1], 𝔼i−1​(ρti−ρti−1)2→0\mathbb{E}_{i-1}(\rho_{t_{i}}-\rho_{t_{i-1}})^{2}\rightarrow 0 and (95) holds with xi2=σti−12​(Δi​W)2x_{i}^{2}=\sigma_{t_{i-1}}^{2}(\Delta_{i}W)^{2}.

Now replace xi2x_{i}^{2} with (Δi​J)2(\Delta_{i}J)^{2} in (95). We need to show

supi𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​𝟏{|xi+ε|≤vn}​Δi​B]=oP​(Δn3/2).\displaystyle\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon|\leq v_{n}\}}\Delta_{i}B\right]=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}). (98)

Note that when |Δi​W|>vn|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n} or |εi|>vn|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}, by Hölder’s inequality, and that P​(|εi|>vn)P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}) and P​(|Δi​W|>vn)P(|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}) decay faster than any power of Δn\Delta_{n} since Δn1/2/vn≪Δn1/2−β\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/2-\beta}, by similar techniques as in (89), we obtain

supi𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​|Δi​B|​(𝟏{|Δi​W|>vn}+𝟏{|εi|>vn})]=oP​(Δn3/2).\displaystyle\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\left(\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}\}}\right)\right]=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}). (99)

And further notice that when |Δi​W|≤vn|\Delta_{i}W|\leq v_{n} and εi≤vn\varepsilon_{i}\leq v_{n}, |xi+εi|≤vn|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} imples |Δi​J|≤C​vn|\Delta_{i}J|\leq Cv_{n} for some positive constant CC that we assume for simplicity is 11. Then by Holder inequality and Lemma 17 in [3], for any p,q>1p,q>1 such that 1/p+1/q=11/p+1/q=1, we obtain

supi𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤vn}​|Δi​B|]\displaystyle\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\right] ≤supi𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​p​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤vn}]1/p​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​Wq|]1/q\displaystyle\leq\sup_{i}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2p}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}\big]^{1/p}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big[|\Delta_{i}W^{q}|\big]^{1/q}
≲(Δn​vn2​p−Y)1/p​Δn1/2.\displaystyle\lesssim(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2p-Y})^{1/p}\Delta_{n}^{1/2}. (100)

By making pp close to 1 and q large, the above bound is of order oP​(Δn3/2)o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}).

What remains to show is to replace xi2x_{i}^{2} with Δi​W​Δi​J\Delta_{i}W\Delta_{i}J in (95). Similar to the case for (Δi​J)2(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}. By Hölder’s inequality, and that P​(|εi|>vn)P(|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}) and P​(|Δi​W|>vn)P(|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}) decay faster than any power of Δn\Delta_{n} since Δn1/2/vn≪Δn1/2−β\Delta_{n}^{1/2}/v_{n}\ll\Delta_{n}^{1/2-\beta}, with similar techniques as in (89), we obtain

supiσti−1​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​J|​|Δi​W|​𝟏{|xi+εi|≤vn}​|Δi​B|​(𝟏{|Δi​W|>vn}+𝟏{|εi|>vn})]=oP​(Δn3/2).\displaystyle\sup_{i}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J||\Delta_{i}W|\mathbf{1}_{\{|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\left(\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}W|>v_{n}\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\{|\varepsilon_{i}|>v_{n}\}}\right)\right]=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}). (101)

And further notice that when |Δi​W|≤vn|\Delta_{i}W|\leq v_{n} and εi≤vn\varepsilon_{i}\leq v_{n}, |xi+εi|≤vn|x_{i}+\varepsilon_{i}|\leq v_{n} imples |Δi​J|≤C​vn|\Delta_{i}J|\leq Cv_{n} for some positive constant CC that we assume for simplicity is 11. Then by Holder inequality and Lemma 17 in [3], for any p,q>1p,q>1 such that 1/p+1/q=1/21/p+1/q=1/2, we obtain

supiσti−1​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​J|​|Δi​W|​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤vn}​|Δi​B|]\displaystyle\sup_{i}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[|\Delta_{i}J||\Delta_{i}W|\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}B|\right] ≤supiσti−1​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​J)2​𝟏{|Δi​J|≤vn}]1/2​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​Wq|]1/q​𝔼i−1​[|Δi​Bq|]1/q\displaystyle\leq\sup_{i}\sigma_{t_{i-1}}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big[(\Delta_{i}J)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{|\Delta_{i}J|\leq v_{n}\}}\big]^{1/2}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big[|\Delta_{i}W^{q}|\big]^{1/q}\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\big[|\Delta_{i}B^{q}|\big]^{1/q}
≲(Δn​vn2−Y)1/2​Δn=oP​(Δn3/2).\displaystyle\lesssim(\Delta_{n}v_{n}^{2-Y})^{1/2}\Delta_{n}=o_{P}(\Delta_{n}^{3/2}). (102)

Then we have proved (33) and Z2⟂Z1Z_{2}\perp Z_{1}. ♢\diamondsuit

A.3 Proof of technical limits in Theorem 2

Proof of (37).

It suffices to prove the following two terms:

A1:=mn1/2Δn−1/2​vn2−Y/2​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​X)2​𝟏{vn≤|Δi​X|≤vn​(1+vnη)}​|Δi​M|]=oP​(1),A_{1}:=\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{v_{n}\leq|\Delta_{i}X|\leq v_{n}(1+v_{n}^{\eta})\}}|\Delta_{i}M|\right]=o_{P}(1),

and

A2:=mn1/2Δn−1/2​vn2−Y/2​∑i=1nKmn​Δn​(ti−1−τ)​𝔼i−1​[(Δi​X)2​𝟏{ζ​vn​(1−vnη)≤|Δi​X|≤ζ​vn}​|Δi​M|]=oP​(1).A_{2}:=\frac{m_{n}^{1/2}}{\Delta_{n}^{-1/2}v_{n}^{2-Y/2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}K_{m_{n}\Delta_{n}}(t_{i-1}-\tau)\mathbb{E}_{i-1}\left[(\Delta_{i}X)^{2}\mathbf{1}_{\{\zeta v_{n}(1-v_{n}^{\eta})\leq|\Delta_{i}X|\leq\zeta v_{n}\}}|\Delta_{i}M|\right]=o_{P}(1).

Firstly we work on A1A_{1}. By Cauchy-Schwarz and Proposition 1, we obtain:
